PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Proposed Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling,Mr Les Johnson,Mr Charles Jones,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Mountford and Mr Scholes.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The hotel industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The hotel industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The hotel industry is almost entirely within the private sector and makes a large contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The hotel industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry's 5811 hotels in Australia.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian hotel industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increase to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The hotel industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives:
1. Recognise the importance and place of the Australian Hotel industry in social and economic life of the nation.

2. Accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bourchier,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Porter,Mr Scott and Mr Thomson.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilizers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cowan and Mr Les Johnson.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls for:
The immediate and unconditional withdrawal of any proposals to deny unemployment benefits to unemployed people under 18 years old.
That the level of benefits for all unemployed people, and including people receiving sickness benefits and pensions, be raised to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line.

That future employment policies be devoted to job creation and the restoration of full employment rather than the evasion of this responsibility by hiding the unemployed in short term training and education schemes.
Public acknowledgement of the fact that unemployment is the result of insufficient jobs and not the fault of any minority group, the education system or the unemployed themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Sir Phillip Lynch,Mr N. A. Brown and Mr Lloyd.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the prospect of the proposed Plant Breeder's Rights legislation. The reasons are as follows.
(1) We believe it will restrict free growing and exchange or sale of non-chemically treated seeds.
(2) We believe it will cause a decline in the genetic diversity of plants as evidenced in Europe following implementation of similar legislation there.
(3) We believe that prolonged public debate is necessary as is a referendum before a final decision is made.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take positive action as soon as possible to arrest the implementation of such legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of children's services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual Budget allocations in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Free and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Discriminatory Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That the right to work without discrimination on any ground including, inter alia, discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, pregnancy, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, is a fundamental human right; and

That it is both the duty and the responsibility of society to fully support those denied work and therefore those who are unemployed as a result of society's inability to provide full paid employment should be guaranteed an adequate income without discrimination on any ground, including inter alia discrimination on grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, sex and/or sexual preference, or pregnancy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate and adequate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, in employment of individuals under federal awards, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to race, ethnic origin, marital status and/or sex.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under ''Cosmetics'' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. The proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a 'poor risk' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. In regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans, it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. The proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. The proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students;
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced;
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance;
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require:
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purposes; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, industry and educational research laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy and Personal Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Paragraphs 107 and 108 of the Privacy and Personal Information discussion paper number 14, brought down by the Law Reform Commission in June 1980, undermines the family unit and the authority of parents, which is the Christian basis of our society, by proposing that ''between 12 and 16 years, a child should be entitled to object to disclosure of information to a parent.''
It is your petitioners sincere belief that:

(a) an adolescent between the ages of 12 and 16 is not at a mature enough stage of life to decide whether or not the disclosure of information to a parent will be in the best interests of the adolescent.
(b) as a record keeper has no responsibility for the child, and as his moral standards may be different to those of a parent, he should not be permitted to come between child and parent.

(c) a parent has a unique position which may enable him/her to perceive a situation that the record keeper does not. The parent must therefore be aware of the problem if remedial action is to be taken, and has the right to guide the child in the direction he/she feels fit.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Members of the House of Representatives will reject the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission and find some other means to protect children from the excessive abuse of some parents.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Breeders' Rights
PETITION.PARA: To: The Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving 'property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Publications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned having great concern at the way in which children are now being used in the production of pornography call upon the government to introduce immediate legislation:
1. To prevent the sexual exploitation of children by way of photography for commercial purposes;
2. To penalise parents/guardians who knowingly allow their children to be used in the production of such pornographic or obscene material depicting children;
3. To make specifically illegal the importation, publication, distribution and sale of such pornographic child-abuse material in any form whatsoever such as magazines, novels, papers or films;

4. To take immediate police action to confiscate and destroy all child pornography in Australia and urgent appropriate legal action against all those involved or profiting from this sordid exploitation of children.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will protect all children and immediately prohibit pornographic child-abuse materials, publications or films.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Owing to an overwhelming and continuous demand by the Australian people for a cruise service within the economic scope of the working man and his family, we request the Government to lift the ban placed on Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels entering Australian Ports.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are gravely disturbed by the actions of militant unions and the ACTU, the failure of the President of the ACTU to assist positively in settling the dispute which has caused massive losses to Qantas our National Airline, and we applaud the action of the Government in using RAAF planes to rescue Australians stranded abroad.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament and the Government should be of firm resolve not to permit such unions to hold the country to ransom and continue to take a forceful and resolute stand against such union militancy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the present government of El Salvador has been responsible for the deaths of at least 10,000 people in 1980 alone; and that it has been condemned as one of the worst human rights violators in the world by organisations such as Amnesty International and the US Conference of Catholic Bishops.
Therefore we humbly request that the government of the Commonwealth of Australia:
(i) urge the government of the United States of America to immediately cease all military aid to the government of El Salvador;
(ii) support the freedom of the Salvadoran people against the governing military dictatorship.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Staging of American B52 Bombers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and Rest and Recreation base for American B52 bombers:

Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it establishes a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the U.S.A. and another power.
Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B52s:
(a) carried nuclear weapons;
(b) were engaged in bombing missions against another State.
Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconcilably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy.

Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region.
Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin, in that noise pollution and the threat of accidental radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents.
Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraw the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B52 bombers. And that furthermore will ensure that any request of such usage by the U.S. Government be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cunningham,Mr Free,Mr Les Johnson,Mrs Kelly and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Raymond Terrace Telephone Exchange
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable Mr Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the residents of the Shire of Port Stephens respectfully showeth that they are dissatisfied with the services provided by Telecom Australia through the Raymond Terrace exchange and sub exchanges and that businesses lose money and citizens are inconvenienced by the many problems found.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will ensure that the services are upgraded as a matter of urgency.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Canned Ham
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain pork producers of the Electoral Division of Maranoa respectfully showeth that importation of canned ham from Romania, Yugoslavia, Holland and Canada is having a disastrous effect on the Australian Pig Industry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that steps be taken to prevent the importation of canned ham into Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Centre: Australian Government Clothing Factory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria respectfully request that the Federal Government keep its promise of 1979 to build a work-based child care centre on land adjacent to the Australian Government Clothing Factory, under the guidelines of the original approved proposal, and that the matter receive urgent attention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vehicle Testing Service: Phillip, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned electors of the Division of Canberra respectfully showeth:

The members of the public are seriously concerned at the drop in the high standard of vehicle testing, when this service is handed over to private enterprise. It is well known that state testing of vehicles, where it occurs, is considerably inferior to that which takes place in the A.C.T.
Considerable capital has been expended to further improve the service at Phillip. This taxpayers money should not be wasted.

If vehicle testing is to be carried out by private enterprise, the public will have to pay a fee. If given the option, they would rather pay this fee to a government agency, in the knowledge that the findings of the test would be completely un-biased, whereas through private enterprise, this may not always be the case.
The south-side population of Canberra are entitled to the service provided by the Phillip Office. It would be difficult to give this service at Dickson due to the limitations of the building.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Two-airline Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the present two airline domestic policy of the Commonwealth Government.
That this policy has resulted in expensive airfares and poor service and discourages tourists from the Eastern States visiting Western Australia and vice versa.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition and formulate an Airline Policy providing for greater competition so that prices and service are determined by free market forces.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House-
(1) congratulates and compliments the French people in displaying the wisdom necessary for the election of a new Socialist President-the first in 23 years;

(2) calls on the Government to seek urgent talks with the new President with a view to discussing the immediate banning of nuclear testing in the Pacific and the question of self-government of French possessions in the region; and

(3) calls on the Government to seek assurances from the Reagan Administration that the Central Intelligence Agency will adopt a policy of non-interference in France to avoid a repetition of the overthrow of the Allende Government in Chile and the Whitlam Government in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, could I say something that might be helpful to the honourable gentleman. On behalf of the Australian Government I have sent messages to the President of France indicating that we would want to work with the President to continue to advance Franco-Australian relationships. Clearly, we will want to discuss a number of matters with the Government of France. I hope that the warm and friendly relationships established under his predecessor will be continued under Monsieur Mitterrand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House is of the opinion that age and service pensions should remain payable to women when they attain the age of 60 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House totally rejects the reasons given by the Prime Minister in depriving the State Premiers of $70m in revenue and calls on the Government to increase its allocation by the sum of $70m forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House rejects the appeal made by the Queensland Premier to the Federal Government to cut foreign aid, and calls on the Government to increase aid to overseas countries to 0.7 per cent of Australia's GNP and increase to 4 per cent the proportion of foreign aid channelled through recognised non-government organisations such as World Vision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Is it a fact that the strongest opposition has been expressed by every State government to proposed cuts in funding to the States, the objectionable manner in which those cuts were achieved, and particularly to cuts in health funding? Is it a fact that both the Queensland and Western Australian Premiers consider the cuts not only wrong on policy grounds but also immoral in the way in which they were achieved, and probably illegal? In view of that, and in the interests of trying to establish some harmony in Federal relations, will the Prime Minister now swallow his pride and recall the Premiers Conference as soon as possible to work out a fairer and more honest deal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arrangements that have been worked out with the Premiers in relation to these matters are fair. They are fair in particular when we have regard to the needs of the taxpayers of this country. At a Premiers Conference during the winter last year, the Premiers indicated to me that they were going to have meetings amongst themselves, excluding the Commonwealth, and that they would then put proposals to us for a review of the tax sharing arrangements because under the original agreements the tax sharing arrangements had to be re-established, re-negotiated, by 30 June this year.

ANSWER.PARA: I put it to the Premiers at that time when they made their own proposal known that it would be much better if the Commonwealth could participate in that discussion with the Premiers. I said that if they did not do that, it could so easily lead to a situation where we have Premiers putting one view and the Commonwealth in the interests of the Australian taxpayers having another view-a situation where it is difficult to get to a final agreement. The Premiers persisted with the view that they wanted to meet by themselves. They met in September. I think letters were sent to me at that time indicating a need for an urgent meeting then to discuss the results of their review but that could not take place because the results of their review did not really come forward until some time in February. So, the Premiers themselves, discussing these matters amongst themselves, took from September till about February to be able to formulate their own view.

The document which they provided to us was one in which firm views were not really put. They argued on the one hand for maintaining a percentage of income tax revenue; they argued on the other the merits of making the percentage a percentage of total taxes. We obviously have examined the States' document in the decisions that we have made. If I might take that one point-a percentage of income tax or a percentage of total taxes to be defined by discussion between ourselves and the States-the second alternative is obviously one that would give the States greater security in the revenues that they have because the fluctuation in all Commonwealth revenues is likely to be to a degree less than the fluctuations that could occur in one particular form of revenue.

In addition to that, since the States had expressed concerns over the previous years that adjustments to income tax should not be made without prior consultation with them-and that obviously put any Commonwealth government in difficulty in relation to the formulation of its own Budget because one cannot discuss major matters of that kind on a wider front-the Commonwealth had come to the view and put to the Premiers that it would be better to relate the funds that go to the States as a percentage of all revenue to be defined rather than as a percentage of income tax. The Commonwealth Government, as a result of reviewing matters that the Premiers put and the reference by the Treasurer and me of these matters back to the Cabinet, had decided to maintain the view that a percentage of all revenue was better from the States' point of view than a percentage of income tax.

There would be no purpose in reconvening the Conference at the present time. It needs to be understood that there will be a meeting with the Premiers in June that has important matters to discuss, including the infrastructure program, the Loan Council programs and the borrowing programs of semi-government authorities and smaller authorities. On that occasion there will be opportunity for the States to raise matters related to those issues. But I should indicate that the main thrust of the Government's decisions in relation to tax sharing has been made. There has been discussion with the Premiers in relation to it. In discussion this morning, the Government made it very plain that in the interests of Australian taxpayers who are interested in smaller government, whether that be from the Commonwealth or from the States, we adhere to the views that have been put and we adhere to the decisions that have been put.

The Minister for Health has also reported to us on discussions which he had. I do not want to make any comment about that at the present time except to say that the main thrust of the arrangements that we have made in relation to health will stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs to recent newspaper advertisements by the Government which promote the employment of disabled persons. Assuming these advertisements are part of a campaign for the International Year of Disabled Persons, will the Minister advise the House whether this is all the Commonwealth will be doing in the field of employment for disabled persons in their designated year? If not, will the Minister advise the House as to what else is being done or planned to be done?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even before the International Year of Disabled Persons the Government clearly recognised the importance of improving the employment prospects of disabled people. This concern has been heightened and emphasised by the fact that this is the International Year of Disabled Persons. Accordingly, the Commonwealth has embarked upon a number of specific initiatives to achieve this objective. In the first place, as the honourable member pointed out, there has been a significant promotional campaign under way to encourage the placement of disabled persons in employment. This program has two stages. The first is directed to senior management and the second is directed to those people in management who actually take people on and employ them in companies and enterprises. Secondly, the Government has also established Commonwealth employment promotion committees in each State and the Northern Territory to look specifically at the employment problems of disabled persons.

ANSWER.PARA: Thirdly, in respect of specific programs to assist the disabled, the Minister for Housing and Construction has already taken initiatives to ensure that improved access is provided for disabled people within Commonwealth premises. It is perhaps not widely known, as it should be known, that there is an incentive available from the Government of some $2,000 for the purchase of special equipment and the making of necessary modifications to the work place to enable disabled persons more adequately to take their place in the work force. In Commonwealth Employment Service offices there are special personnel who are attuned to the needs and specific requirements of disabled persons. This likewise is making a very substantial contribution to enabling disabled persons to obtain employment. The Commonwealth is doing all those things and more. I can assure the honourable member that, especially through the work of the State committees, the Commonwealth is determined to make every effort to adapt the work place as far as possible to the needs of disabled persons and to ensure that as many disabled persons as possible are placed in suitable and satisfying employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his statement late last week in which he refused to recall the Premiers Conference and said that the Premiers would not get another cent or another dollar. I ask: Does he still stand by that statement? Under what circumstances would he have been prepared to advance to the Premiers the extra $70m which the Cabinet had apparently approved?

—The honourable gentleman has a misunderstanding of the negotiating mandate that the Treasurer and I had on that occasion. It is perfectly plain that a Cabinet is capable of expressing a view to a Treasurer and Prime Minister and saying: That is the maximum extent to which you can go but we do not want you to go anything like that far. That is precisely the situation the Treasurer and I were in. We negotiated within the authority. It is not a question of there being an extra $70m. That money would have to be prospectively taken off the taxpayers of Australia to be paid to the Premiers. It is not a question of the $70m being in somebody's kitty or up in the sky. It is a question of its having to be prospectively taken from the taxpayers of Australia to be paid to the Premiers or somebody else. The Commonwealth has made the decision that that ought not to happen.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that off-shore oil search has been inhibited because the industry is not permitted to import foreign rigs? Is it true that the industry stands to lose up to $35m if it does import a rig and then a local rig becomes available? Why is there this protection for local rigs? Has the Minister knowledge of the approximate total cost to the Australian community of protecting Australian vessels from competition? If not, will he seek to obtain that information and make it public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The policy that the Government has pursued for some time is administered by the Minister for Industry and Commerce and me to provide protection to the Australian shipbuilding industry. This policy has been under some criticism by companies wishing to drill for oil off-shore. I have had a number of representations from people expressing concern about the matter. As a result of that concern the policy is currently under review to ensure that it does not unduly inhibit, or add to the costs of, oil search in this country. I do not have at my fingertips the actual cost of this policy, and any costs associated with it, but I will make sure that I get the information that the honourable member requires and make it available to him. If it is necessary, I will make it publicly available.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said, the policy is under review. At present I am not aware of the policy having had an impact on any particular company. We have had discussions with a number of companies and I think their requirements have been adequately met as a result of negotiations that have transpired. We will not inhibit the oil search program with a policy that could provide an impediment to oil search generally in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, relates to the letter from the Premier of Western Australia to the Prime Minister. Does the Prime Minister agree with Sir Charles Court's statement that the States' share of personal income tax is theirs as of right, being equivalent to taxation reimbursement arrangements which have existed since 1942? Will the Prime Minister make a reality his claim to decentralise financial responsibility by holding what Sir Charles calls 'proper consultation' rather than unilaterally dictating what funds the States can receive? Since the States together have the legal power to control the Loan Council, what action will the Prime Minister propose should the States decide to make up for the cuts in their general assistance grants by increasing their borrowing?

—The honourable gentleman would be well advised to wait until the Loan Council meeting takes place before he decides what can or should be done in relation to it. I can assist him to this extent: In relation to the infrastructure programs where some States have claims for massive increases which would double the size of the total program, before a project can be approved there needs to be a simple majority of the Loan Council, of which the Commonwealth must be a part. The States are examining at the moment whether they, as States, see any particular level at which the borrowing requirements of the States would be too high. It will be interesting to see what judgment they make on that but obviously the Commonwealth is in a position of being able to make its own judgment if it has to. It is odd for governments to look upon the taxpayers' funds, whether from income tax or some other tax, as belonging to any government as of right. I believe that the funds earned by taxpayers are theirs as of right and that governments need to justify spending that part of people's incomes which the governments do spend.

—Can the Minister for Health advise whether the Government takes a soft line with doctors who defraud Medibank? Is it true that members of the medical profession, because of their status, are able to pull strings to avoid action or are less likely to be thoroughly investigated for possible fraud under the Medibank system? Is the Minister satisfied that penalties provided for and imposed, both of a monetary and a gaol term nature, are adequate? Finally, is the Minister aware of and concerned about a report that a Canberra doctor who pleaded guilty to 183 charges was fined $27,800 but as an alternative had to serve only six days in gaol?

—I would like to confirm to the honourable gentleman and to the House that the Government in no way takes a soft line in relation to fraud of Medibank or other Commonwealth moneys, whether that fraud be perpetrated by doctors, patients or any members of the other professions involved. In fact, as you would remember, Mr Speaker, I have been criticised by some people for the way in which the Commonwealth follows up allegations of fraud in relation to bills presented to the Commonwealth by particular members of the medical profession. In saying that, I do not want to give the impression that a large number of people are involved--
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. I draw your attention to Question on Notice No. 2202, parts (2) and (3).
—This question deals with a different issue and is in order. I call the Minister.

—I want to confirm to the House that there is no way that this Government would agree to any proposition that people could pull strings to avoid prosecution for fraud. I am sure that the Opposition would agree with me in that approach. I have been concerned about some of the penalties imposed in relation to matters of fraud. My attention was drawn to the case of the Canberra doctor who elected to spend some time in gaol rather than repay a certain amount of money. It is my belief that the magistrate who imposed the sentence did not believe that the result which actually occurred was in contemplation or would occur. Obviously, it is a matter for some concern and one which I am presently considering in relation to an appeal.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry. Is it a fact that all private wool testing firms in Australia have failed? Is it a fact that the Australian Wool Testing Authority is an official, independent and impartial body of absolute international reputation which costs government nothing and levies charges lower than any other test house in the world? Is it a fact that if the Australian Wool Testing Authority is sold, there is every chance that wool sales may have to be cancelled, and that the cost of wool testing will rise by 40 per cent to 50 per cent? If so, can the Minister inform the House of the benefits to the Australian wool industry and Australian taxpayers if the Government proceeds with its plans to sell the Authority?

—Whilst I can understand the purpose behind the honourable member's question, I have to point out to him that there is a great deal of guessing involved in some of the figures which he has used. The real test that had to be applied to the Australian Wool Testing Authority, when the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee looked at it, was whether there would be any detriment to the industry were the Authority to become a private wool testing house. The second test to be applied was whether there would be any detriment to the wool growers separately were the Authority to become a private testing house.
—Yes.

—The honourable member says: 'Yes'. He knows all about it. He knows that in New Zealand, for example, private wool testing houses are used. He knows that in the United Kingdom private wool testing houses are used. These private wool testing houses have achieved the same high reputation as has the Wool Testing Authority in Australia. On all the criteria that are applied to the matter, it cannot be claimed at this point that any real detriment would occur to either the industry or the wool growers if the Wool Testing Authority became a private wool testing house. That is the first point to make. With respect to the second part of the honourable member's question concerning the transfer of the Australian Wool Testing Authority, it is our intention to give it adequate time within which to prepare for an orderly transition from a government-owned organisation to a private test house. Thus there should not be any delay or hiatus in the issuing of certificates. It should prove possible to transfer the organisation as a going concern. I point out to the honourable member that all his fears will prove to be nought.

—I direct a question to the Treasurer. Investors interested in the film industry in Australia have expressed apprehension in backing productions currently scheduled to commence filming in Australia and, in particular, in the Northern Territory. Can the Treasurer indicate when legislation is to be introduced to clarify the position to ensure that planned film time tables can be met?

—I have indicated previously to the House in response to a similar question that it is our intention to introduce that legislation with a request to Parliament for its passage before the winter recess. That remains the intention of the Government.

—I ask the Minister for Communications whether it is a fact the Broadcasting and Television Act presently requires a person to be an Australian resident to escape the limitations placed on foreign ownership of broadcasting licences? Has the Government, as was reported in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, decided to replace this measure by the qualification of Australian citizenship? I ask the reason for this change and whether such a change would then be inconsistent with the taxation Act and the Foreign Takeovers Act?

—The honourable gentleman will know that that definition is available to any honourable member by looking at the existing legislation. I suggest that the honourable member should not take that much note of some of the rumours he reads in the Press.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. No doubt he is aware of the fact that at present there are two takeover proposals announced in respect of two trading banks. Many people would regard a licence to conduct banking business as an extremely valuable asset. Arising out of those comments I ask the following questions: Firstly, has the Treasurer given consideration to the sale by tender or by some other appropriate means of licences to conduct banking business? Secondly, if not, will he take that subject under examination both in respect of licences that may become surplus if either or both of the proposed takeovers are successful, or in respect of any other licences that may be granted at any time in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in the suggestion made by the honourable member. Certainly, it is the fact that the issue of a banking licence confers upon the recipient of that licence an extremely valuable asset. That is more particularly the case under existing policy whereby considerable restrictions are placed upon those persons or organisations which can hold banking licences. As I think the House will be aware, the subject of the regulations under which banks operate in Australia is one that has been examined very closely by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I expect that that Committee will report in August or September of this year. I would be surprised if the Committee did not have something to say in some detail about banks and banking practices and the conditions on which the Government ought to approach banking operations in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: In those circumstances, the type of proposal that the honourable member has in mind obviously could be considered by the Government in the context of looking at the Campbell Committee's report. Some differences exist between the considerations that bear upon the sale of privileges of that kind by tender in respect of other industries and those that might bear upon the sale of them in respect of banks. In any event the question loses some of its relevance depending upon the extent to which one removes the restrictions on the granting of licences.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the figures released yesterday showing that the level of capital inflow in the March quarter of $1,705m was the highest ever recorded. I ask: Is it a fact that a very high proportion of this capital is being brought to Australia as portfolio investment to buy shares in existing Australian businesses and not for the purpose of establishing new industries? Will the Treasurer tell the House what procedures, if any, are employed by the Foreign Investment Review Board to monitor the level of foreign portfolio holdings in Australian com- panies and what criteria are used to arrive at the classification of certain shareholdings as Australian? Finally, what steps is the Government taking to protect the Australian ownership of existing businesses against the capricious investment policies of large foreign companies and large foreign institutions?

—I am aware of the figures referred to by the honourable member for Blaxland. They are further evidence of the attractiveness of this country to foreigners as a place in which to invest. Much and all as those on the opposite side of the House complain and find it a matter for adverse comment, this country is regarded as having a stable economy. That is precisely why there is such very heavy investment in this country. The honourable member for Blaxland knows as well as I do the provisions of the Foreign Takeovers Act which relate to the acquisition of Australian businesses, he knows as well as I do the provisions of the foreign investment policy so far as they relate to new projects, and he knows as well as I do that the high level of portfolio investment in this country is a tribute to the success of this Government's economic policies.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is a Standing Order which provides that answers should be relevant to the question. I addressed to the Treasurer a question not about takeovers but about the cancerous behaviour of this buying up of shares in fairly small parcels by a myriad of institutions overseas. They are not takeovers as block investments. I want to know what the Government's attitude is to the buying up of Australia in parcels by a number of institutions, whether this is monitored and what the Government will do about it.

—The answer given by the Treasurer may be construed by the House as not being an answer to the question asked but the answer was relevant. The House will make its own judgment as to the value of the answer.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Goodluck proceeding to address a question to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will rephrase his question.

—I refer the Treasurer to his statement yesterday on the two proposed bank mergers in which he said that his general view was that strong national interest considerations would need to be involved before the Government sought to interfere with normal commercial processes. In view of the fact that these mergers would reduce the number of banks by one-third and concentrate almost half of the assets of all financial institutions in the hands of four banks, thereby reducing competition and providing more scope for excessive profits, is the Treasurer seriously suggesting that strong national interests are not involved? Further, would it not be more appropriate for the Government to put the onus on the banks by requiring them to demonstrate that strong national benefits would result from these mergers before they are allowed to proceed?

—The problem with the honourable member's suggestion is that it ignores the provisions of section 63 of the Banking Act which provides that the consent of the Treasurer is required for a merger and that that consent will not be unreasonably withheld. That is utterly inconsistent with the course of conduct which is suggested by the honourable member. To suggest that to put upon those seeking consent the onus to demonstrate the national interest meets the requirements of a provision that consent should not be unreasonably withheld is an odd construction of the language of section 63 of the Banking Act. I have indicated that the Government has yet to receive formal applications in respect of either of the mergers that have been mooted in recent days. When those formal applications are received, consideration will be given promptly to the question of consent under section 63. I expect the parties seeking approval for the respective mergers will, in their applications, address a number of things, including such matters as the question of future staff arrangements and the provision of an adequate branch network to service the needs of different parts of the country. There are a number of other matters which no doubt will be addressed by the banks in making their applications. A judgment will then be made on the basis of the applications put forward by the respective parties. I repeat the view I expressed yesterday, that strong national interests need to exist in order for the Government to interfere in what are essentially commercial arrangements between financial enterprises in this country. In company with a lot of the comment that has been made in other places about these mergers, the honourable gentleman talks as though the only banks in Australia are the six trading banks, including the Commonwealth Banking Corporation, which was referred to in his question. I remind him that a significant number of State banks are in existence in Australia and that, since the last occasion on which there were significant mergers between trading banks in this country, there has been a very major change in the structure of the financial sector in Australia and there has been a significant rise in the contribution of merchant banks. There has been a significant rise in the strength and the contribution of building societies offering, as they do, a number of facilities which are offered also by parts of the trading bank structure. It is a total misunderstanding of the Australian financial system to talk as though it is entirely constituted by those six trading banks.

—I refer the Minister for Primary Industry to the Government's proposal to sell some wool stores to private enterprise. Can the Minister advise the House of the Commonwealth's equity in wool stores? Is it a fact that the rationalisation of these stores will result in increased costs to wool growers?

—As described in the report of the Australian Wool Corporation, the Commonwealth's equity in wool stores covers the Corporation and the public equity in the land and in the stores held by the Corporation. It is true that the Corporation had an obligation in times of emergency to store Australia's wool clip. That obligation will be maintained in the future. But it is also true-I think it is agreed-that there are a number of wool stores that are surplus to the requirements of the Wool Corporation. We on this side of the House believe that it is not appropriate that a government monopoly, such as the Corporation, in this sense ought to be competing with the private sector in the leasing of stores that are not used for their main purpose. Therefore the decision has been taken that, after discussion with the Wool Corporation, some of the stores should be sold. I do not know where the honourable member gets the idea that in some way this will create an extra cost to the wool grower, but I will look at that aspect of his question and see whether I can give him any further information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to his election statement of 9 October 1980 in which he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I repeat the words 'absolutely no truth'-
in the statement that the Government was planning to restrict patients' free access to public hospitals by reimposing a means test for hospital care.
Was this merely a contingent electoral statement, dispensable when the election was over, or was it an example of the new law of politics advanced by the Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will not argue the case. He can seek information.
—I simply wish to ask: Does this statement reflect the Minister's view that 'no government can keep promises which are not consistent with its policies'?

—I think it has to be brought home to the Opposition that the Government's philosophy in relation to centralisation of control in Australia is very different from the Opposition's philosophy. The Government believes that the constitutional responsibilities of the States involve the provision of public health services and include the provision of public hospital services. A decision as to whether a means test will be imposed for access to public hospitals is entirely a matter for the States concerned.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COSTS OF CONSULTANTS AND CONTRACTING SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Have government departments been instructed not to prepare separate estimates for the costs of consultants and contracting services in the future? Would such a course make it almost impossible for the Parliament to identify and scrutinise these costs? If instructions have been issued in this connection, what are they and what are the reasons for them?

—I cannot answer the honourable gentleman's question. I will speak to the Minister for Finance about it and I will provide what information I can. I can say that it would certainly be a matter of concern if the capacity of this Parliament to scrutinise expenditure by government departments was in any way watered down by the actions of government. I am sure that that is a view that would be shared by my colleague the Minister for Finance. Beyond that, I will seek further information.

—I refer to the claim by the Minister for Health that the Government's new health insurance arrangements are based on the user pays principle. Can the Minister say whether this principle could or should be extended to other health areas-for example, to such public health facilities as baby health centres and immunisation programs-all of which are currently free at the point of delivery? Does he believe that hospitalisation for other acute forms of medical disorder should be treated differently from hospitalisation for psychiatric disorders which is provided free in all States except New South Wales?

—The general philosophy behind the Government's changes to the health insurance arrangements is well known. We believe that those people who can afford to make a contribution towards their health costs should properly do so, but also that those people who are in genuine need in the community should be protected. In fact the Government's changes achieve both of those objectives. It is a matter for State governments to make decisions about services provided by them.

—I direct my question to the Minister for the Capital Territory. On 19 September 1980 the then Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Ellicott, announced that an international convention centre with hotel and office accommodation would be built in Canberra on sections 11 and 60 in Civic. The closing date for submissions for that project was 1 December 1980. Will the Minister explain why that project will be now 'postponed indefinitely'? Will the companies who prepared submissions be compensated for the incorrect information given to them? Does the Minister acknowledge that this project would have been a great incentive to the tourist industry and the Canberra economy? Does he acknowledge that the convention centre and hotel could proceed without Federal Government assistance if a casino were included in the project? Will he advise the Minister for Industry and Commerce that his figures of record investment in the hotel industry in the Australian Capital Territory, as stated in the Canberra Times of 6 April 1981, are now wrong?

—The decision announced by the Government following the Review of Commonwealth Functions was that no funds would be made available for the convention centre in 1981-82. In addition a statement was clearly made that none of the tenders was acceptable to the Government. I repeat for the benefit of the honourable member and others that there is nothing to prevent any corporation, group or consortium establishing a convention centre in Canberra. The honourable member might be interested to know that as recently as yesterday an indication of interest in establishing a convention centre in Canberra without government support was communicated to me.
—With office accommodation too?

—Indeed. If the honourable member had paid any attention to the discussions which took place relating to the proposed convention centre she would know that it was proposed that office accommodation would be available. One area was to be for the potential use of a government department. I suggest to the honourable member that, if she is genuinely interested in pursuing the establishment of a convention centre, she should do as I am doing and support any group which is prepared to invest in the national capital. If the honourable member accepts the proposition that there are people prepared to invest, she can go into the market place with me and support the cause. Lastly, in relation to the comments attibuted to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, the Minister's figures are not incorrect.

—Has the Prime Minister studied the text of the agreement reached last week between Japan's Prime Minister and President Reagan? Is he aware that, under this understanding, for the first time, Japan will play a strategic role-as opposed to simply deploying a self-defence force-in the Pacific? Given the importance of this development for Australia, was the Government informed in advance by the United States Government and, if so, were our views either sought or offered?

—For some time discussions have taken place between the United States Government and the Australian Government at different levels on the role that countries around the Pacific, including Japan, might be able to play or, in the view of some, ought to play in the general defence of the whole theatre. For example, the honourable gentleman will recall that, as I understand it, over the last year or perhaps the last two years units of the Japanese fleet have in fact participated in the Rimpac exercise. I think that indicates a degree of changed circumstances. In short, there have been discussions over a period relating to the subject raised by the honourable gentleman.

—The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), speaking in a debate on voting rights for migrants, is reported at page 2126 of Hansard as having said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not uncommon for us as members of the Federal Parliament to be assailed by people at meetings and elsewhere about matters which we know are within the purview of local government or State government. Indeed, the honourable member for Hindmarsh once raised a matter at Question Time, I recall, with my colleague the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) about a matter that was fairly and squarely within the realm of a State Minister.

DEBATE.TITLE: NORTH WEST CAPE NAVAL COMMUNICATION STATION AGREEMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On 5 May this year, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) repeated to this House two demands for renegotiation of the North West Cape Naval Communication Station Agreement. These were demands he first stated when he spoke to the National Press Club on 14 April 1981. The demands are:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, that Australia's consent is mandatory for all orders to initiate military action which flow from the station; and secondly, that we be given firm and convincing assurances that the station will not be used to send orders for a first-strike nuclear attack or to initiate a limited strike.

Responding to my statement that these demands amounted to an Australian veto over United States use of the North West Cape Station, and that it was unreasonable to expect the United States to co-operate in such a veto, the honourable member said:

Does he know what the two most senior people in the American Embassy, apart from the Ambassador who is yet to arrive, have declared to me, to members of my staff and to at least one of my colleagues that they find no problems with what we are proposing. They understand completely our concern about national sovereignty. They believe they can work with the proposal.

I immediately had inquiries made of the United States Embassy about this statement by the honourable member. On 6 May, the United States Charge d'Affaires, Mr Stephen Lyne, wrote to me in the following terms:
Dear Mr Minister:

Statements made in Parliamentary debates yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition regarding the installations jointly operated by the Australian and US Governments in Australia have come to the Embassy's attention.

The Hansard for May 5, 1981, quotes Mr Hayden as stating that senior Embassy officials told him and his staff that they found ''no problem with'' and ''can work with'' his proposals. I wish to clarify that, insofar as Mr Hayden's statement refers to his two proposals that the North West Cape Agreement be renegotiated to provide for mandatory Australian consent to initiate military actions and convincing assurances that the Station not be used to send orders for first-strike nuclear attack or to initiate a limited strike, the Embassy did not give such assurances nor did it have the authority to give them.

With the Embassy's permission, I now table this letter. Although marked confidential the letter has since been declassified. I should not wish a misunderstanding between my honourable friend and officers of the United States Embassy to become the central feature of our discussion of this important topic. My honourable friend might have misinterpreted some general comment by the Embassy-to the effect that, should a Labor government come to power, the United States Government would discuss any concerns about the facilities that that government might raise. This seems to me the sort of response that one would expect from an Embassy in such circumstances.

Let me add that it would really be fruitless for us to become side-tracked by this issue. Clearly we cannot know how a United States government might respond to the Labor Party's demands regarding the North West Cape agreement until the Labor Party is able to form a government and formally put its proposals forward and require a governmental response. This is not the position at the present time. It remains for me to say that if there are some further briefings that my friend would like then I would be quite willing to facilitate those briefings at his convenience. I present the following paper:
North West Cape Naval Communication Station Agreement-Ministerial statement, 12 May 1981.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) proposed:
That the House take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts in relation to what it is claimed I said, as outlined by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen), are correct. That is, I did say that the two most senior people at the American Embassy-the Ambassador not being present and therefore not included in that count-conveyed to me, members of my staff and at least one of my colleagues, on separate occasions, that they can find no problems with what we are proposing overall concerning my statement of 14 April to the National Press Club, which included, specifically, reference to the North West Cape. They stated that they understood completely the Opposition's concern about national sovereignty. They said that they believed they could work with the proposal. Mr Speaker, that is what I said was stated and I stand by my statement. There can be no ambiguity as to what was conveyed to me. The Minister for Defence was generous enough to say:

SPEECH.PARA: My honourable friend might have misinterpreted some general comment by the Embassy-
If I misinterpreted the general comment of Embassy spokesmen, so did several other people, mainly members of my staff and at least one colleague.

I give honourable members the facts for the record so that there is no doubt about the circumstances and the justification in association with my claim. On 14 April I addressed the National Press Club. It was a speech which covered, first of all, the relationship between the super-powers concerning nuclear strategic doctrine and matters associated with that. It then related to joint defence facilities in this country-Nurrungar, Pine Gap, Smithfield and North West Cape. I then outlined the reaction of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen), who accompanied me on my visit to those facilities and both before and after that visit participated with me in quite extensive briefings and inquiries we projected at the people conducting the briefings at the Department of Defence. In relation to North West Cape I expressed certain reservations about the implications of how that facility could operate. I will not go over that. But, after I spoke I left the hall where the Press Club luncheon which I addressed took place and went to the bar-a perfectly understandable reaction.

TALK.START.PARA: —I went there, too.

—Yes, and we both enjoyed good company. My private secretary, Mr Mike Costello, was standing in the foyer near the reception desk. He was approached by Mr McAndrew of the American Embassy. Mr McAndrew said, explicitly, the things I have stated. He not only stated them-voluntarily-but also he said them in the hearing of my Press secretary, Mr Alan Ramsey. A little later Mr McAndrew entered the precincts of the bar at the National Press Club. He approached me and repeated those things to me. He repeated them in the hearing and presence of another member of my staff, Mr Michael Roche, a research officer, who heard the full discussion. Some of that discussion was overheard by Mr Costello, who had joined us. Subsequently, I think in the first week of the Easter recess, but certainly during that recess, Mr McAndrew called at my office in Canberra. I was absent. He spoke again with Mr Costello and repeated the views which I have put; that is, that the Americans found no problems with what we were proposing, that they understood completely our concern about sovereignty and that they believed they could work with the proposals. That, comprehensively, was their view. There were no ifs or buts, no qualifications and no special reservations about any aspects of those proposals, including North West Cape.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Gareth Evans tells me that unsolicitedly-all of these comments were unsolicited-Mr Stephen Lyne, charge d'affaires of the American Embassy, approached him and said exactly that too.
