TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in tabling the science and technology statement 1980-81. I seek leave to make a statement in connection with this document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's aim is to advance the welfare of the Australian people. The great social and humanitarian reforms of the last century were largely possible because of increased industrial productivity, better health services and improved communications. Science and technology played a major role. It is equally true that science and technology will underwrite Australia's economic and social development in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Questions of the Government's role, the ways of co-ordinating science policy and establishing priorities must fall within this aim. The first science statement was tabled last year and I believe the document was a major development in helping to answer science policy questions. It provided a new basis for analysis, observing changes and providing data.

The response to the science statement has been positive and this year it has been expanded to cover not only research and development but also a range of scientific and technological activities. It is now the science and technology statement, not just the science statement, and some new figures have to be treated cautiously. It is a post-Budget analysis of Commonwealth expenditure listed by agency, Ministry and by socio-economic objectives. I would like to thank fellow Ministers, their officers and the Australian Science and Technology Council for their help in compiling the statement.
Development of Science and Technology Policy

In formulating Government policies towards science and technology, both long and short term factors have to be examined and taken into account. Over the past decade there have been significant changes in community attitudes to science and technology which cannot be ignored. Presently there is concern about job replacing technology, the environment, the availability of a highly skilled work force and a continuing supply of energy. In addition, I sense a growing fear of the impact of science and technology among the less well informed.

Looking towards the year 2000 there are several factors which will have an important impact on science and technology policies. Some examples are the emergence of new technologies, such as biotechnologies and micro-electronics, changes in the patterns of energy supply and demographic changes. Coherent and far-sighted policies are needed to meet these challenges. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has pointed out that these challenges and changes will require a different sort of policy response-one in which science and technology policy is taken together with economic and social policy.

Australian science itself must also recognise these changes and respond to them. This is as much the responsibility of individual scientists as it is of governments and other bodies responsible for formulating science policy.
Government role

The Government is determined that the science and technology sector should not be considered in isolation. It must be linked and co-ordinated with other sectors such as manufacturing, tertiary and primary industries and energy to form a coherent research policy to meet national goals. Scientific, economic and social policies must be integrated. At the same time the public must be kept continually informed. Society should not be put in a position of being swept along by new developments without influencing their direction. This is the basic reason that I have produced the science and technology statement. To help meet these objectives a four point plan was outlined last year in the science statement. The plan balances the demands for science and technology to meet community needs and problems with public concern over possible side effects from new technologies. The plan is to stimulate and support basic research, applied research, to transfer research results into the market place and to minimise any undesirable impacts of new technologies.
Government Support for Industrial Research

Apart from establishing policy and priorities, governments are examining the extent to which they should promote innovation through funding of basic research and industrial research and development. This question was discussed at an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development Conference of Science and Technology which I attended earlier this year. Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development reports are challenging the prevailing economic wisdom that the solution to current economic problems lies solely with conventional demand management mechanisms. Major recommendations focus on the critical importance of restoring declining innovation. Co-ordinated technological and economic policies must be used to create a growing economy. Governments throughout the world have accepted this premise.
For the information of honourable members, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Declaration adopted by Ministers at the OECD meeting.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ANNEX
Declaration on Future Policies for Science and Technology

Ministers responsible for policies concerning science and technology in the OECD Member countries* and in Yugoslavia, meeting in the framework of the Committee for Scientific and Technological Policy of the Organisation;
Recognising the essential contribution of science and technology to the economic and social development of both industrialised and developing countries;

Recognising that common challenges now face Member countries, such as the slow-down in economic growth, high levels of unemployment, low rates of productivity increase, persistent inflation, structural imbalances in their economies, increased energy prices and environmental problems;
Recognising that science, technology and innovation have a vital role to play in the resolution of these difficulties and in responding to the needs and aspirations of society;
Recognising that fundamental research plays an indispen- sible role in the generation of ideas and new knowledge, including those needed for future technological innovation;
Recognising that national policies have an important influence on the vigour of the scientific enterprise and innovation;

Recognising that progress in science and technology depends upon many forms of international co-operation and on the widest possible circulation of ideas and new knowledge between scientists, between institutions and between countries;
Recognising the value of continuing international consultation on the formulation, implementation and assessment of policies concerning science and technology;
* The mention of Member countries is deemed to apply also to the European Communities.
DECLARE

That it is necessary to integrate policies for science and technology with other aspects of government policy, particularly economic, social, industrial, including energy, education and manpower policies;
That the following require attention in the formulation and implementation of policies for science and technology in Member countries and in Yugoslavia:
A. With regard to technological innovation, steps to:
(i) promote innovation as an objective within the framework of economic, social and regulatory policies;

(ii) assign priority to investment in research, development and innovation so as to ensure that short-term pressures do not jeopardise the sources of future economic growth; higher levels of employment and structural adjustment.
(iii) develop favourable conditions for innovation, including the openness of markets, and encourage risk-taking in innovation in the public and private sectors;
(iv) give particular attention to the innovative potential of small and medium-sized firms;
(v) stimulate research, development and innovation to increase the effectiveness and quality of output in the public and social services sectors;
(vi) stimulate research, development and innovation related to worldwide problems in such areas as energy, raw materials, environment, food, urban conditions, health and the work environment;
(vii) promote the diffusion of technological information;
B. With regard to long-term research, steps to:
(i) maintain the strength and continuity of fundamental and long-term research to increase the stock of basic scientific and technological knowledge throughout the range of disciplines:

(ii) reinforce the research capacity of the universities and other relevant institutions, having appropriate regard to problems of their funding, administration, research facilities, staffing, and their links with industry and the public sector, and with other sectors of society;
C. With regard to the social, economic, cultural and political effects of technological change, steps to:
(i) take due account of the social and cultural implications of new technologies, in respect of the employment, mobility and training of the labour force;
(ii) monitor the introduction and spread of new technologies while attempting to assess their possible future implications for the economy, the environment and society;

(iii) facilitate public participation in the definition of major technological orientations, particularly through public access to information concerning their foreseeable long-term impacts, and through fostering public understanding of science and technology;

D. With regard to international co-operation in science and technology steps to: (i) stimulate the exchange of scientists, engineers and students between Member countries, facilitate the exchange of scientific and technical information, and encourage the flow of technologies;

(ii) explore new opportunities for co-operation in areas of common interest, with a view to making more effective use of human resources and major research facilities, to sharing of costs, to obtaining more rapid results, and to mounting large-scale efforts where these are necessary for an effective attack on problems;
(iii) encourage at the international level measures conducive to an improved scientific basis for regulations in areas such as health, safety and the environment;

(iv) pursue a broad range of activities in co-operation with developing countries to strengthen their scientific and technological capabilities, and contribute to the implementation and assessment of these efforts;
Ministers further declare that OECD should:

(i) give increased emphasis to the integration of scientific and technological factors within the activities of the Organisation and, in particular, within its work on the various aspects of economic policy;
(ii) improve the understanding of factors underlying the innovative performance of Member countries, and of the effects of international transfers of technology;
(iii) assist the less-industrialised Member countries as they tackle the problems of increasing the contribution of science and technology to their economic and social development;
(iv) continue the exchange of experiences and information among Member countries concerning policies for science and technology, and facilitate the definition of such policies;

(v) facilitate the assessment by Member countries of the consequences of technological change upon economic growth, rates of employment, productivity increase, structural changes in the economy, upon the environment and upon society at large;
(vi) facilitate the identification by Member countries of both research areas in which they would wish to co-operate and arrangements conducive to such co-operation;
(vii) facilitate the efforts of Member countries to strengthen the scientific and technological potential and capabilities of developing countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The Australian Government has been involved in 'pump priming' industrial research and development through the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme. It is the Government's plan to use the scheme to increase employment, raise productivity and maintain the competitiveness of Australian industry. This year $53m is being spent. We believe this investment will repay itself many times over in the future. My Department has conducted a survey of estimated benefits which companies expect to receive this decade from project grants under the scheme. The companies estimate that new sales generated in this period will total $8,600m in domestic sales and a similar amount in exports. Jobs created will be an estimated 29,000.

SPEECH.PARA: Applied Science

The Government is continuing to support Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation research aimed at assisting Australian industry. In particular, CSIRO is stepping up its work in the manufacturing and energy sectors. A new Division of Manufacturing Technology has been created. Initially it will focus on the processing of metals and computer-aided manufacturing.

Also CSIRO is establishing a new Institute of Energy and Earth Resources formed from existing CSIRO energy research activities and the non-nuclear research sections of the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. Research will be expanded in such areas as fossil fuels, mining of energy resources, energy conservation, alternative fuels and renewable energy. Policy will be formulated in co-operation with my colleague, the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick). In marine sciences, CSIRO will be expanding activities also to assist the fishing industry and the exploitation of off-shore resources.
Basic Research

I have concentrated mainly on policy considerations, particularly in meeting practical problems. Basic research must not be ignored. It is a paradox that, in order to apply science more directly and effectively to problems, we must extend our knowledge of basic science. Without this foundation successful technology transfer will not be possible. Basic research must be funded at a realistic level without necessarily being measured against short term application. The need of man to extend constantly his knowledge of himself and the universe is an undeniable argument for the funding of basic research.

The Government mainly funds basic research through the Australian Research Grants Scheme, the Australian Marine Sciences and Technologies Advisory Committee and the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council. Over the past few years the Australian Science and Technology Council has examined the role of the Australian Research Grants Scheme, the role of university research, the objectives of funding basic research and the appropriate levels of funding. The Government has agreed to a recommendation from the Australian Science and Technology Council that the role of the Australian Research Grants Scheme must be used to support the most outstanding research projects. We have agreed also to an Australian Science and Technology Council recommendation that the universities themselves should allocate their internal research funds to give greater support for good quality research. Even greater emphasis will be placed on excellence as the basis of the Australian Research Grants Scheme support for research.
Role of private sector

I am concerned that the private sector is still not investing enough in research and development. The Industrial Research and Development Incentives Scheme has arrested an alarming slump in industry spending in this area during the mid-seventies. There has been a slow upturn and I am challenging private enterprise to increase its spending in this important area. Research and development are essential if we are to compete internationally. Yet OECD figures indicate that spending by Australian industry is very low compared with other Western countries. I would like to see research and development spending by industry more than doubled in this decade. The whole innovative process from invention to commercial marketing will have to be strengthened also in line with this aim.

The Australian Government makes an unequal contribution to research and development spending in Australia, currently accounting for about 70 per cent of the estimated total of $1,200m. The Government should not be expected to upgrade that figure further unless industry also greatly increases its research and development funding. It is in the interest of the private sector to increase its own effort and, in so doing, create new jobs. Industries not willing to do this run the risk of being left behind, and, as such, should not expect government protection. Australia's financial institutions also have been tardy in providing risk capital to develop and commercialise new products and processes.

Along with resources development, the creation of specialised high technology industries is necessary for Australia's long term economic well being. My Department has conducted forums bringing together financiers and high technology entrepreneurs. Matters discussed included changes to the capital market, establishing a specialist venture capital financing body and taxation incentives. We are planning also a high level symposium bringing together the Academy of Technological Sciences, financiers, and the Government to look at these points. The House will be aware that the Campbell Commission of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System is examining these and other related points.
Conclusion

Australian science and technology policy must be integrated with economic and social goals. If not, the nation's scientific and technological resources will be wasted. All sections of the economy must play their part in supporting science and technology if Australia is to be counted among the technologically advanced countries of the world. High technology industries must be created. Present industrial processes and products must incorporate the latest technology and must be basic research promoted. Australia must maintain and improve its data base of technological and scientific knowledge otherwise we will lose jobs and business opportunities to other countries.

We must not forget that science is a cultural activity essential to the spirit of mankind. This Government has adopted policies aimed at making the best use of science and technology for the economic and social advancement of all Australians. In pursuit of these goals, the Government is acting to minimise the undesirable social consequences of new technologies. A special sub-committee of the Australian Science and Technology Council has been established to advise the Government on this matter. The science and technology statement will be the factual basis on which scientists, policy makers and the public can work. I present the following paper:
Science and Technology 1980-81-Ministerial statement, 12 May 1981.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Fraser Government's provocative and improper appropriation of funds due to the States.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fraser Government's provocative and improper appropriation of funds due to the States is a national scandal. It is the cause of notorious comment throughout the media. It has established widespread public disgust at the squalid way in which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) went about this exercise. All that it has achieved is a split in the Government ranks and a welding into a common front of the State Premiers-regardless of political philosophy-determined to repudiate this tawdry behaviour by both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Howard). It is in this respect that the Prime Minister is not only answerable but also responsible to this Parliament. One would never presume this to be a fact. It is almost impossible to capture the Prime Minister in this Parliament so that he will participate in a debate in which he should properly present the Government's defence of its actions which have led to widespread discontent and condemnation. This is such a case. I guess the greatest difficulty the Prime Minister has with a debate like this is, being unwarned several days beforehand, he has no opportunity to recycle the old speech which we heard on the occasion of the resignation of the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), and last week on the occasion of the censure motion moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we have a Prime Minister in control of the affairs of this country who, after some 30 years in this Parliament, is terrified at the prospect that he might have to participate, off the cuff, in a debate in defence of his Government and his actions. I have to confess that I too would be terrified. I think the task is beyond human credulity or ability. Why will the Prime Minister not come into this Parliament and defend the Government, its actions and his own intolerable behaviour? I repeat, we have a Prime Minister, a parliamentarian, who is absolutely terrified of the proper processes of parliament. So we have this situation where Question Time is an empty farce with the Prime Minister droning on endlessly and irrelevantly to questions which are put-the knight behind the doleful countenance. The forms of the House have to be exploited by the Opposition in a desperate effort to draw the Prime Minister into debate in this Parliament.

I give honourable members this fact so that it is understood on the record: The only way in which we can feel some certainty, but not total certainty, the only way in which we can draw the Prime Minister into a debate in this Parliament to defend properly his Government, its actions and his behaviour, is to move a censure motion. However, it seems to me that to move censure motions week after week is a very inappropriate procedure and an improper standard to establish. Yet what alternative is left to the Opposition? It debases the coinage. But it is the only measure which is available to us if we are to have the Prime Minister speak to us. He does not speak to his own members much so I suppose we should not cavil too much. But he should speak to the people of Australia and outline a defence of what his Government is about and how it got the country into this shambles. It is one of the strongest and wealthiest economies inherently in the world. There is no excuse for the problems that we have had in the past several years under the Fraser Administration. The fact is that administration of Government is in a state of suspense as a result of the internal brawling of this Government. There should be an explanation.

I ask honourable members to consider these facts: Six months after the third election success of the Fraser Government, at a point, therefore, when it should be bathing in the full flush of success, we find it in total disarray. Five and a half years after the initial election of the Fraser Government, at a stage when there should be no doubt as to the direction or the nature of policy, with no requirement for refinement that would arise with a new government because of the novelty and difficulties of certain policies, we find that there are no policies and no programs and there is no direction for this country. Instead we have a government that is reeling about and tripping over itself like a drunken man on a mindless binge. It is directionless, it is careening about in a storm of distress that is created by its own incompetence. Regrettably the nation is afficted by a crisis prone Prime Minister. Look at some of those crises such as the Peacock affair and all of the unseemly, dirty washing hung out for the view of the community. Another crisis involves the freedom of information legislation. The Government senators believed the Prime Minister when he said that he wanted freedom of information and now he cannot understand why they are trying to establish that. Another one is the broadcasting and television legislation amendments, the Murdoch amendments-the deal for a mate, as it were. It is a total corruption of the proper processes and standards that one would expect in national government.

It is bad enough under the backwards standards that apply in the Parliament of Queensland and under the Premier of Queensland. It is intolerable that there should be such a diminution of standards at the national level. The uncertainty and conflict about civil aviation policies, the confusion about health policies and, of course last but not least, the conflict over the States all boils down to this: The affairs of this country, a strong and secure country which is entitled to confidence, are being run by a man who is inherently insecure. Day by day he is trying to prove to himself that he is tough and he tries to do that at the expense of his colleagues and at the expense of the unity and harmony of this country. Some time ago he said that it was his purpose in government to establish co-operativeness with the States. I shall quote him exactly from his 1975 policy speech, in which he said:
We will provide a sound basis of financial independence and responsibility for the States and Local Governments with the most significant reform of the federal system since Federation.
Our policy has been hailed around Australia by State and Local Governments.
It is the greatest advance in Federal-State relations since Federation.
That was all said before the Government tried it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he leak that?
—He is prepared to tell the public about that. The following year in December-bear this in mind because it is just so delightful and delicious-he said:

SPEECH.PARA: So, if these developmental proposals are to work it will require the kind of co-operation that comes from people of our political philosophy; the sort of co-operation that one finds from Sir Charles Court or Mr Hamer . . .

Should I say: 'Enough said'? Sir Charles Court, Mr Hamer, and every Premier in Australia now know that Fraser federalism is nothing more than a knee capping exercise designed to cripple the States. Let us hear what Sir Charles Court said about his colleague and friend, his party associate. He said that the Prime Minister's word is valueless and that the Prime Minister is dishonourable. He said that the Prime Minister disregards the States and that he has converted States into departments of the Federal Government. He goes on in an ancillary fashion to say that the hospital arrangements he is proposing are nothing more than a tax trap for the States whereby, in fact, they will end up far, far worse off. Of course by re-arranging the basis for funding the States from income tax revenue to the total of revenue, he aims at disadvantaging the States because the fact is that with the elimination of tax indexation in any form at all the public will be paying $1,000m more in tax than they would if the Government had honoured its promise to preserve or to establish full tax indexation. I ask honourable members not to take this from the Australian Labor Party because it may be a little prejudiced. Let us get an open mind on this at least. Let us go to the South Australian Premier, Mr Tonkin. He said: 'I have never seen anything so inept in all my life in politics'. He should be in the Labor Party. We have been saying that for years. He continued:

Obviously the Commonwealth regards the States as members of a kindergarten. The Commonwealth was dishonest with us and did not give us our fair share. I cannot tolerate dishonesty. Our relations have been damaged irreparably. The whole thing stinks. In two words Mr Bjelke-Petersen said: 'It is a crooked deal'.

Sir Charles Court's searing condemnations were contained in a letter which he sent to Liberal members of parliament and which has been telexed to the newspapers of this country. I repeat that it is a condemnation from a friend who knows the Prime Minister better than any of us. He said that the Prime Minister is dishonest and dishonourable. He cannot be trusted. His word cannot be relied on. There can be no confidence in an association or in a working relationship with a man like that. That is the standing of the Prime Minister with Sir Charles Court. The $70m that the States have been deceitfully deprived of is important in a symbolic sense because it shows the sorts of qualities the Prime Minister applies in government and in his negotiation with responsible public figures regardless of how close they may stand to him in political texture. It is important also because it shows the qualities of a cheat and a sneak. Those are squalid qualities.

This is not a game of fiscal bingo in which the Government is running a country, conducting the affairs of the nation and administering the national economy. It is a matter of responsible fiscal administration. The Government, in its negotiations with the States, establishes the level of expenditure which is proper for the States to receive. It allocates funds to the States on that basis. Those funds are not the Government's funds; they are the public's funds. They go back to the States to benefit the people living in the States. I repeat-I say this on the basis of experience as a former treasurer-that the assessments are made quite austerely and the States are not funded too abundantly. We are all in the same boat. We cannot have abundant funding because of limited resources. But it is nonsense to talk about parameters and the option for movement within those parameters and then, like a cheap braggart, give the story to the Press and expect that there will be no reaction. I guess that it is the quality of a braggart which more than anything else has offended the Australian community.

The amount of $70m is small beer to the States in terms of the overall disabilities that they will suffer. One must admit that the State Premiers have been particularly green in buying this fiscal version of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. But it is also symptomatic of the way in which the affairs of the Fraser Government are conducted. We have the Fraser Government leaking to the Press but not prepared to talk to the Parliament. Let me tell honourable members about the real nature of the disabilities. The total allocation of funds available to the States in real terms has been hacked back quite dramatically as against the preceding year. That will mean more unemployment at one level or another; it will mean more government charges. At the State level, they are inequitable charges and they will be inflationary. It will mean a reduction in the standard of services and the range of services available at the State level. In 1980-81, the actual allocation to the States is $6,541m. The amount that should have been allocated to them if allowances were made for inflationary movements and movements in population and wages was $6,821m-a $280m shortfall, to which must be added a shortfall of $267m in the health allocations. The States will have to make up the shortfall in one way or another. The total amount is nearly $550m. Let us project that figure in terms of employment-the total number of jobs at risk involved with that sort of shortfall. Directly, nearly 46,000 government employees could lose their jobs. But the multiplier effects will reach out into the community and into the private sector. When these government employees lose their jobs, they will not spend money. There will be contractions elsewhere and there will be a multiplier figure of three, not the ignoble multiplier of 10, 12 or whatever figure strikes the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) when he is in the House. That will take the number of jobs in jeopardy to nearly 137,000. They will not all be lost in the public sector because governments will raise charges, but reducing spending outside government to pay for these things will reduce the number of jobs outside government. The State governments will not increase the employment of people at the rate they should to maintain standards. The consequence will be a diminution in standards.

Commonwealth-State relations are in a shambles. They are overridden by an atmosphere of total distrust. The Government is about to go into the June Loan Council meeting with this atmosphere prevailing. It will be a Loan Council meeting at which an impasse will arise. I want to move in a positive sense to suspend Standing Orders. I move:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving-

That this House, in the light of the Prime Minister's admission that the States have been deprived of $70m to which they are entitled and the clear evidence, therefore, that the Fraser Government is appropriating funds to its own use which properly belong to the States, directs the Government to reconvene the Premiers' Conference immediately for the purpose of:
(a) Making the additional $70m available to the States; and
(b) taking such other steps as will restore the confidence of the States in the integrity of Commonwealth-State relations.

The problem is that the events of the past fortnight have confirmed and emphasised the flaws which we always knew existed in the Fraser Government. It is a government which lacks personal honour and integrity, a fact which the Premiers and the citizens of the States have discovered to their cost. It is a government that is paralysed by the open divisions and bitter rivalries that fester within it. This Government which, at the last three elections, has promised us reliable and responsible administration, instead has reduced the nation to chaos and confusion. This Government, which is prepared to do nothing but favours for its few friends, is incapable of bringing harmony and unity to the nation. If we ever needed proof of these fundamental truths about this Government, we had it pushed in our faces by the extraordinary events of the past two weeks. By its disgraceful and deceitful behaviour, the Government has forfeited the trust of this Parliament and the respect of the Australian people.

For the reasons outlined today by my leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden)-I believe they would be supported by the whole nation-it is important that the Premiers reassemble in Canberra next week to tell the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) clearly the real needs of their States. These are matters coming from the Premiers. They want to reassemble here next week because they have made very clear that they have rejected the offer made by the Commonwealth. The only reason they got an additional one per cent was on the basis that there had been incorporated in the revenue grants money that had previously been allocated for specific purpose grants. Wherever one turns at the present time and whatever city one is in in Australia, one finds a whole nation in uproar because the Premiers-State leaders-have been deceived and cheated of moneys to which the Australian people are rightfully entitled. Let me place on record that every dollar that is received by way of tax is taken out of a constituent's pocket. Is the Government now saying that the States have to find more money for schools, hospitals and transport? If so, people will have to pay additional State taxes. That is a form of double taxation. It is for that reason that the people are prepared to decimate the Government at the polls. If the Government were to go to an election tomorrow, it would be lucky on the basis of what has happened to win even 20 seats. Every Premier would be working against it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't believe that.

—I believe it because I thought that normally you were honourable in your approach. But the Government has given itself away in recent days. Once a person, no matter what walk of life he is in, is found to be someone whose word cannot be trusted, he will never get any more support. The problems facing this country at the moment are immense. The proposition that the Commonwealth Government as the tax gatherer is going to cheat and deceive those who pay taxes will bring about its undoing. It is for those reasons that we encourage the Government to bring the Premiers here next week, offer them the $70m--

Let there be no doubt that that consultation was held not only in consequence of the terms of the existing legislation and particularly in terms of the section which I have just read, but also in terms of the points of understanding which govern the financial arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States. But, ultimately, as in all cases in which one party has to make a decision on how much money is to be provided and other parties have to make decisions on how that money is to be spent, there has to be a point at which a decision is made by the Government to provide the money and that, of course, is what has happened in this case. TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Amendment Bill. At the outset, I would like to say that the Bill does reflect on the opportunism of the Government at an earlier time, namely in 1977, when the beef industry had been in a state of crisis for some three or four years and the Government decided to have yet another early election. Sir John Kerr was very happy to oblige in that regard and so a cooked-up scheme was introduced. This scheme was investigated by the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts after the Auditor-General had pointed to certain deficiences in it. I congratulate the government of that day. At least it made some response to the industry at that time. That is very unlike the situation which exists today. The situation today is that the Government is rapidly abdicating its responsibility for Australia's great rural industries. It is doing that at a very rapid rate of knots. What we have now is a sort of razor gang approach to every area of policy in this country, even agricultural policy. What we are getting is ideology, not an analysis of the industry issues and problems. What we are getting is a foisting of functions on to the States and not an examination of the functions of the industries.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us go back to 1975-76-1974 even-when the beef industry first started to get into trouble. That was in the day of the Labor Government. Some $19.6m in carry-on finance provided jointly by the Commonwealth and the States was allocated for assistance to the beef industry. In 1975 the Labor Government allocated some $28m to the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia to assist the beef industry. The Labor Government of the day also made a reference to the Industries Assistance Commission for short term assistance to be provided to the beef industry. That assistance was provided in the Budget which was rejected by the Liberal Opposition at the time, with a little assistance from the Senate and Sir John Kerr. There was a response in that Budget to the beef industry. The Australian Labor Party, when in government, was developing a policy response. It was assisting the beef industry because it was in dire trouble at that time. In the first Budget which the present Government brought down-incidentally, the then Opposition accepted our Budget figure of $19.6m that was allocated jointly by the Commonwealth and the States to assist the beef industry-some $11.3m was taken up. By that time the Industries Assistance Commission's short term report had been brought in. By and large the report advocated that a continuation of short term assistance by way of loans be extended to the beef industry. The then Government said that it would allocate another $15m in 1976-77. That was a sort of response to the IAC short term report which was printed on 23 October 1975. If one looks at the Budget documents at that time one will see that by 1977-78 all we had was some reference to the fact that assistance to the specialist beef producers was now merged with the rural adjustment schemes. As I said, it was about this time that the Government felt another early election coming on; so it cooked up this scheme. Having hammered the ALP right through 1975 and after, doing nothing through 1977 and 1978 but only carrying on in a half hearted manner with the schemes that the Labor Government had set in train-there was no improvement-it decided it had to do something very quickly.

The Beef Industry Incentive Payments Scheme was to provide assistance to beef producers between the period from 23 September 1977 to 22 September 1978. By and large the Bill which we have before us now is to tidy up that scheme. We are talking about a scheme which originated three or four years ago. We are still trying to tidy it up. The scheme set out an eligibility rate of $10 per head of cattle for producers with a minimum of 50 cows up to a maximum of 200 cows. Supposedly one had to engage in some sort of treatment of the animal to get the $10. Basically, all one had to do was slap a cow on the bum to get the $10, but at least it was a response. The scheme was attempting to find a way of putting some money into the hands of beef producers. Part of the problem, in terms of interpreting the way in which the Department of Primary Industry had to process the claims, was because the legislation was regarded as beneficial legislation, in other words, welfare legislation.

If we look at the time scales and the problems the Department faced at that time-here I refer to the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of which I was a member-we find the following statement in the report of the Public Accounts Committee:
Throughout this inquiry, the Committee--
That is, the Public Accounts Committee-

recognised the short time scale given to the Department to implement the Scheme. The Committee concurred with the Department's attributing much of the blame for the subsequent difficulties to the urgency of introducing the Scheme. The Committee was advised of the chronology of events leading to the initial payments made under the Act. This timetable appears at Appendix 4A. Seven weeks elapsed from 44 the initial Cabinet Decision that there should be a scheme until enabling legislation was assented to, and a further three weeks until the first payments were made. The Committee agrees with the Department that the Scheme was conceived in undue haste and led to administrative difficulties.

The Government should not place the blame on the Department. If we look at page 66 of the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, Parliamentary Paper No. 277/1979, we see the rapid haste with which the Government introduced this half-baked scheme.

At the time the Government came down with a great song and dance about this proposal. Forms were circulated throughout the country; a lot of money was spent on publicity; and away the scheme went. Even though the Government carried on in a half-hearted way, at least it was a response to the industry's problems at that time. The Australian Labor Party measures of assistance to the beef industry were at least a response to the industry. Today we do not have any such responses by the Government to the problems of the beef industry. Today the problems of the beef industry do not concern price but drought, stocking levels, abattoirs, and the processing industry. The beef herd is down to about 25.5 million head and the eastern States are experiencing a great drought.

What has the Government done for the beef industry in recent years? After removing export inspection charges it brought them back in 1978-79. It has all but abdicated national responsibility for drought relief. Let us set out what this Government has done. This Liberal-National Country Party Government has refused again to accept its proper share of drought costs. Until 1978, the New South Wales Government, if we are just to take an example, agreed to pay the first $5m for drought relief and the Commonwealth undertook to pick up the rest of the tab. In June 1978, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony), in his capacity as Acting Prime Minister, took a decision to change the formula. It was typical of the sleight of hand which characterises this Government in all of its dealings so notoriously exemplified at the Premiers Conference the other day. Without any consultation, the Deputy Prime Minister changed the formula so that that State would have to pay the first $10m and $1 for every $4 thereafter each financial year.

With the drought continuing with all its severity into its third winter, the consequences of this sort of scheme promise to be ruinous for the farmers in New South Wales and the finances of New South Wales and other States affected by the drought. We should have none of this nonsense about the so-called National Country Party protecting the rural community from the worst ravages of Fraserism and the new federalism. They are up to their neck in it. The New South Wales Government has developed the most comprehensive package of drought relief measures in the history of New South Wales. Despite severe financial restraints-I draw attention to the action of the New South Wales Government because it has copped a caning in this House-the New South Wales Government increased the limit for carry on loans from $5,000 to $10,000 in April 1980, from $10,000 to $15,000 in September, and from $15,000 to $20,000 in October 1980. The maximum loan for farmers entering their second year of drought is $40,000. The limit for restocking loans was raised from $12,000 to $30,000 in December 1980 by the New South Wales Government. In October 1980, the New South Wales Government increased the rail freight subsidies from 50 per cent to 60 per cent. From 1 May 1980, the rebate applicable for owner-carriers under the drought water cartage subsidy scheme was substantially increased. At present in New South Wales road transport subsidies are available in respect of movements of stock to agistment, stock to further agistment, stock returning from agistment, restocking and fodder movements. Stockowners in drought declared areas are being paid $15 a head compensation. I could go on. The New South Wales drought scheme is most favourable when compared with others. In my view the abuse that has been heaped on the New South Wales Government with respect to drought measures has been rather misdirected.

In addition to the drought problems being experienced by the beef industry, we have big problems in the processing industries. Hundreds, if not thousands, of abattoir workers are out of work. Abattoirs are being shut down throughout the country. The New South Wales Government, for example, has had to make available assistance worth $5.1m which will apply from 1 January this year. It has paid out $8.25m since 1975 and all of that mainly since 1 January 1981. The figures to which I am referring are for local government abattoirs. The indebtedness of abattoirs in New South Wales is at present at least $50m. The private abattoirs are in a like situation. The end of the drought will make this situation worse for the abattoir industry because there simply will be no beasts for a considerable period. At the same time the abattoirs are paying something in the order of $16m for the meat processing export inspection levy of $1.80 alone. I realise that this Government will not entertain any reallocation of the $5.82 being paid by the industry which cannot be inbuilt into prices or costs.

I think the Government needs to give some attention to problems being faced by State governments with respect to the abattoirs that have had to shut down or are being financed. It should give some consideration also to the beef industry by way of taking on some of these costs. The industry cannot pay these costs. If the drought ends, the situation will get even worse. I point out to the House that the Federal and State governments guaranteed a $9m loan to the Consolidated Farmers and Graziers abattoir in Victoria but they are not prepared to do anything about the industry as a whole. If I were less charitable I would ask: Whose mate is involved down there in Victoria? It seems to me that the Government is prepared to respond sometimes but only for individuals, whereas it is not prepared to do anything at present for the industry as a whole.

This is in keeping with the general direction the Federal Government has taken with respect to assistance to the rural sector and its policies to the rural sector. It is trying to get out of program or commodity assistance. This Federal Government-there is a lot of evidence for what I am about to say-seems to be trying to transform rural policy into guarantees for statutory authorities and it is hopeful of achieving a system whereby taxation deductions satisfy for everything else. If one looks at the razor gang report and some of the actions of the Government over the past year or two, one sees that it has consistently been trying to get out of quarantine, forestry, soil conservation and meat inspection. From the report of the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems-I know that this report is still under consideration by the Government and State Ministers-it appears to me that the Government is indifferent as to whether the Commonwealth should continue with meat inspections. The Government is trying to get out of rural research and extension. It is trying to get out of reconstruction. It is even trying to get out of dealing with the locust problem. Somehow it believes that if it sacks the 18 people on the Australian Plague Locust Commission, locusts, grasshoppers and whatever one wishes to call them, will no longer cross State borders. One does not need to go on.

In the rural area the Government is very consistently trying to get out of program or commodity assistance. It is trying to foist functions on to the States. It is backing up the statutory marketing authorities. It is trying to solve a few other problems by taxation deduction measures. I do not think the Government is concerned about the needs of Australia's primary industries any more. The National Country Party has become a miners' party. I am not talking about miners at the mine face but about owners of the mines in the boardrooms in New York, London and Tokyo. The rest of the time the National Country Party seems to spend fighting with the Liberal Party for some of the provincial parliamentary seats. It is no longer a national party. It is no longer a country party. It has said nothing about the 5.2 per cent revaluation in the last year or so. It is saying nothing about what the impact of the so called resources boom will be on the rural sector in terms of access to finance or the infrastructure costs that will be imposed on the States. Nothing has been said about the fact that a lot of money that used to go to local government in the country areas will not now go to it due to the mining boom. The National Country Party is saying nothing about these things.

The Bill sets out simply to remove an anomaly which affected the amounts that could be paid in partnership payments. The Opposition offers no objections to it. However, we take the opportunity validly to criticise the Government because it is not doing anything much for the beef industry. The scheme is really a device to give beef farmers money and nothing more. As I have said, the application forms were given to every post office, bank and pastoral agency prior to the 1977 election. The scheme had a large advertising budget. Of course, much of the motivation to introduce it was to save the seat of Capricornia, but subsequently it was lost. Due to the haste with which the scheme was concocted, administrative bungles quickly appeared. The Auditor-General's report of 1978-79 pointed to overpayments which subsequently totalled $432,000. The scheme overall cost $118m. The present amendment is designed to legitimise $700,000 worth of what could be regarded technically as overpayments. The scheme was designed in haste as an electoral bribe and, as a result, hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money was overpaid. We do not know how many people had their hands in the till or how many fiddles were perpetrated.

Most importantly, the scheme was pretty useless in terms of helping the beef industry. After all, $2,000-that was the maximum-is about the price of eight or nine head of beef in a good year. It is well below the poverty line in terms of supplementing the incomes of producers. It was a scheme cooked up in haste. I appreciate the need for the Government to correct some of the existing remaining anomalies in it, but I hope that it will not entertain taking on such a scheme again simply for electoral purposes, designing it in so much haste and requiring the Department of Primary Industry to institute administrative procedures with no time to think them through, to look at the structure of the industry or to work out all the problems that could be faced. It was a most unfair task to give to the Department. At least, as I said, it was a response to an industry's problem at that time. The Government today does not seem to be willing to respond to any element of Australia's great rural industries. It is not prepared to respond in a proper way to the drought in the eastern States at present, particularly in New South Wales. It is not prepared to respond in any way to calls by the Australian Meat Council, the abattoirs and the processors of meat. It is not prepared to look at the real issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr F.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Amendment Bill 1981 which is to validate the existing procedures under which the Department of Primary Industry makes payments to beef producers under the Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Act of 1977. The Beef Industry Incentive Scheme was introduced by this Government in 1977 to assist the beef industry which at that time faced serious difficulties. It indicated the interest of the Liberal and National Country parties in the beef industry, which is one of our great primary industries. Cattle producers were assisted with a payment of $10 per head for cattle receiving approved husbandry treatments during the 12 months from September 1977. Payments under this scheme were limited to 200 head of cattle with a maximum payment of $2,000.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme was aimed at providing a cash flow for cattle producers. The Government provided $118m under the scheme. It was well received by producers and, as I have mentioned, it indicated the Government's concern for the industry, which is so important to Australia, both internally and in terms of exports. Beef exports have been amongst the three top agricultural exports of this country. Wool, wheat and beef are the backbone of Australia's primary industries and, indeed, our total exports. This Bill removes an anomaly in the 1977 Act which affected amounts which lawfully could be paid to certain claimants. Under the principal Act producers may be eligible for incentive payments in their own right or as members of groups of joint cattle owners nominated to receive and distribute the payments. It was made quite clear, however, that payment to one owner could not be made for more than 200 cattle or exceed $2,000.

The anomaly which the Bill sets out to correct concerns groups of producers who between them own more than one cattle herd. As the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) stated in his second reading speech, an example is the case of two producers who each have cattle of their own and who, as partners, also own a herd. As the 1977 Act stands, a payment of $2,000 to a partnership disqualifies the partners for any future payment in respect of their own individual herds. Conversely, when claims were first lodged and paid in respect of the individual herds, each of the owners could receive $2,000 or a total of $4,000 between them, but if this occurred the partnership would not qualify for any payment.

Other anomalies could occur, depending on the order in which claims were presented. Apparently it was the intention of the Act and the practice of the Department of Primary Industry to treat two or more claims by a person so as to maximise the payments to that person by ignoring the order in which claims were made. Clause 3 of the Bill validates the procedure of the Department of Primary Industry by making the necessary amendment, which is back dated to the commencement of the principal Act. Provision is also made under the amendment to increase past payments to the maximum payable where this has not already occurred. The amendment provides a safeguard to ensure that no legally made past payments become overpayments as a result of this legislation.

In the first instance the Department of Primary Industry assessed claims made by sole proprietors separately from claims submitted by partnerships. This resulted in overpayments and, as the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has said, these totalled $432,000 on 300 claims. It is very interesting to note that 83 per cent of those overpayments has since been recovered. There is no doubt that efforts will be made to recover the outstanding 17 per cent. The recovery of overpaid funds has been a successful achievement. Honourable members may recall that these matters were commented on by the Auditor-General in his 1978-79 report to the Parliament. There is no doubt that the urgency of the occasion demanded that the Government immediately bring down legislation to assist beef producers who were in dire straits because of drought throughout Australia. Many beef producers did not have sufficient funds to carry on their normal everyday life. This Government saw to it that cash payments were made to them.

Country abattoirs have been mentioned in the debate. There is no doubt that the abattoirs in the State which I represent are in serious trouble. From observations and experience in the beef industry I have no doubt that it is over-serviced. We have too many abattoirs in New South Wales. When we have a rundown in cattle numbers and sheep numbers, what is the result? These abattoirs are in financial trouble and they run immediately to government for assistance. It is known that a number of them are local government abattoirs. Of course, they are being supported financially by a State government, so they run to that government for financial support. If the abattoir situation in New South Wales had been properly planned by the New South Wales Government the abattoirs would not be experiencing the trouble that they are experiencing today.

It is good to see the Minister for Primary Industry at the table. Dual meat inspection has been a great problem in this industry for very many years. It is good to know that the Minister will make every effort to iron out this situation at the August meeting with the various State Ministers for Agriculture. Dual meat inspection is costing huge sums of money. It is affecting the prices paid by the housewives to the butcher shops. The honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) would know all about that because he has considerable dealings with housewives concerning the supply of quality meat. If we get rid of the system of dual inspection of beef it will be of great benefit not only to the honourable member for Parramatta but also to the industry right throughout Australia.

Cattle numbers in this country are down; there is no doubt about that. Several years ago these numbers were to the order of 32 million. As has been stated tonight, they are down to approximately 26 million. Most of those cattle are in Queensland. New South Wales is experiencing the worst drought it has ever experienced. If we go into the winter without any water and with a shortage of feed we will witness a devastating scene. That will happen if we do not get substantial rain within the next few weeks. The meat industry is in dire straits in New South Wales. This is, of course, affecting employment in our country towns. A country abattoir of any size employs from 350 to 400 men, and if those men lose their jobs it is a disaster for the financial and economic situation of the town in which it is located. The works with which I am connected has been reasonably fortunate. It has been able to maintain its work force and to kill something like 1,500 head of cattle, 10,000 head of sheep and 1,000 head of pigs. It is not a profitable operation but it is fortunate that it is in a status quo situation.

The honourable member for Werriwa mentioned the investigation of the scheme by the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts. He was a member of the Committee, and at the time so was I. The honourable member mentioned that there was undue haste in the bringing in of the 1977 legislation to assist the cattle producers. That legislation had to be brought in hastily because of the situation in which these people found themselves. It is not unusual under those circumstances to find some anomalies. The Bill with which we are dealing eliminates those anomalies and creates a splendid situation as far as the industry is concerned. It was said that the New South Wales Government is providing great assistance as far as drought relief is concerned. What a lot of rubbish! Here we have a situation where funds are available, as the Minister for Primary Industry has informed us, to the State Government for drought relief if it asks for them. Of course, the situation is that these funds are available after the State Government has spent $10m. The Minister knows only too well that we have taken this matter up with him from time to time and he has informed us that no efforts have been made by the State Government to apply for additional funds which are available to us. The State Government ought to be more appreciative of the drought situation in New South Wales and approach the Federal Minister for funds which, we understand, will be readily available.

With regard to the export of our beef, it was a great tragedy when we lost the European Economic Community market. A market for 80,000 tonnes of beef was lost just through the stroke of a pen. It appears that it will be very difficult for us to get back into that market, as the Community is dumping cattle on the market for $300 a carcass. That makes it terribly difficult for Australia's beef industry to enter the European Economic Community. So we have to find other markets for our beef. The Department of Primary Industry and the Department of Trade and Commerce are doing just that. The beef industry is one of the greatest primary industries in this country and we should be looking after it. I have no doubt that the Minister for Primary Industry is doing that.

I support this legislation in its entirety. I have no doubt that it will go through here today because members of the Opposition are not going to oppose it. They have had a few pertinent remarks to make about it. Just the same, the Opposition knows that it provides for a good scheme. It knows that anomalies will be eliminated from the 1977 legislation and that that will be good for the cattle industry and those associated with it. The legislation has my full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Amendment Bill, I will make just a few comments. Before I get on to the Bill, I will cover some of the points raised by the honourable member for Paterson (Mr O'Keefe), who covered a fairly wide range of subjects to do with agriculture. He mentioned the drought assistance provided in New South Wales and condemned the New South Wales Government for not doing enough for drought relief. He said that that the Federal Government stood ready to assist. Anybody who realises the situation would know that the States are requested to spend $X before the Federal Government makes any move at all. But, from the evidence presented to this House in the last few days and the actions of this Government in the way it treated the States, I do not think there would be anything stopping this Government, if it really were serious about assisting the primary producers in New South Wales, from making money available. From what we have seen, the Government is quite capable of pushing the States around in any way it likes. I do not think that there would be anything stopping the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) or the Government from making funds available.
—The State governments have to ask for it.

—The honourable member for Paterson says that the States have to ask for it. For the last week we have heard them asking for the $70m they are entitled to. Yet supporters of the Government stand up in this House and say that the States have to ask for the money before it can be put across. The Government has the money and is refusing to give it to them. The States should not need to ask the Federal government for the money; it should just give it to them and they will spend it in the right places.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1977 this Government introduced a scheme to assist the beef industry. At that time the industry was in the middle of a world-wide slump-we all admit that-brought about by an excessive supply and a slump in demand. The slump was brought about by economic factors which had a lot of their roots in the dramatic increase in the price of crude oil. Many sectors of primary industry were affected by the downturn in the world economy at that time. Whilst all clear-thinking people are well aware of the necessity to assist those primary producers in need, the actions of the Fraser Government in 1977 when it introduced the Beef Industry (Incentive Payments) Bill were actions of that Government at its cynical best. At that time there were 85,900 beef producers with 50 or more head of beef cattle and 32,390-odd of them who owned 200 or more head. To put this whole debate into perspective we have to assess what was being provided by government at that time, why there was this need for this money to be available in this matter. Measures of Commonwealth assistance were available to the beef industry to alleviate the depression which had gripped the world trading economy at that time. These measures included appropriations of $20m to the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia in 1974 by the then Labor Government. There was a further $8m in 1975 to be lent to viable beef cattle producers under the schemes keeping those farmers in business. The States Grants (Beef Industry) Act 1975 provided for the beef carry-on loans scheme.

This Government has been preaching of the need for less Government expenditure ever since it engineered its return to the Treasury benches. In this context it is interesting to relate how this Government used the Act, the amendment to which we are debating today, to assist many wealthy supporters of the Government. When we look at the numbers of farmers with 50 or more beef cattle-85,900 beef producers-we see that many of those farmers are very wealthy, with assets by the million and with no need whatever for a hand out of $2,000 from the public purse. With the assistance that the Commonwealth Bank had in train it could have quite easily done the job that this Bill sets out to do three years later. But instead the Government took the approach of handing out $2,000 willy-nilly, whether the people require it or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —You try to tell the beef growers that.

—The Minister can tell it to the beef grower who never received the funds. He can tell it to the one who got $2,000 and who did not need it. The Government wasted the money where it could have given $4,000 to the fellow who perhaps went broke because he could not get that extra $2,000. Where is the means test in the way the Government approaches things? It gives money across the board to anybody. It is also handing out public funds.
—You are not talking sense.

—The Minister says that I am not talking sense. On what basis, in any other schemes, does the Government hand money across the board to those who do not need it? It has a means test on pensioners. Where public public funds are accounted for in other departments, it is always done on the basis of need. Education grants are given on the basis of need. The Government does not just hand the money across the board to people who do not need it. The Minister preaches that the Government must cut its expenditure, yet it went ahead and spent something like $118m to $120m. That is money that could have been spent on much more worthwhile efforts in the last couple of years. We had a debate in the House last week on quarantine and surveillance of the coast of this country. We have no money to do that, yet the Minister wasted money on wealthy people. In relation to this Bill the Government is not concerned with cutting back expenditure when it comes to handing across money to its own supporters, but it is very savage on government expenditure when it deals with people who are really in need of funds.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General looked at this matter and found gross over-payments. What sort of a Bill was it? Would the Commonwealth Bank's approach have allowed that sort of thing to happen? I have dealt with that type of approach, and there is no way an organisation like the Commonwealth Bank would waste money the way this Government wastes it. The honourable member for Paterson said that the Government had got 83 per cent of the money back. What about the other 17 per cent? Are we ever going to see that again or has it gone down the gurgler, as they say? What a great way of running the country, is it not? Maybe some beef producers were very happy to get the $2,000 but I do not think I know of anybody who, if they were handed $2,000, would not say, 'Thank you very much' and take it. I am not arguing the point that those people were not appreciative that they got their money. They probably bought a slightly better car than they normally would have. Needless to say, an election for Capricornia was going on at the time. I would say that was probably the main reason for the haste to get the message across to the people at that time that money was available to those who supported the Country Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very generous of you.

—The Minister interjects, but the Bill is just one of those Bills that every now and again we see the Country Party and this Government bringing into this House, rushing it through and getting it passed to help its own supporters. It is not so anxious today to bring in legislation that will really help the Australian public. It puts away millions of dollars and sends it, as I said before, down the gurgler. We will never see any benefit whatever from it.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to speak for a long time in this debate but I refer to a few more of the points which were raised by the honourable member for Paterson. He referred to the fact that the abattoirs are in trouble. They are in trouble all over the country, not just in his State. Even though this Government spent some $118m over a short time in the beef industry, the numbers of beef cattle have continued to decline to the stage now where there is a massive over-supply of abattoirs and they are in trouble all over the country. It will be many years before there is a rebuilding of the herds to overcome that problem. I just say to the Minister that we hope we do not see this type of Bill introduced and this type of method used to support a section of the community where public funds are sent right across the board and are not accounted for.
