TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose this very simple Bill. The purpose is to amend the Pig Slaughter Levy Act 1971 to raise the maximum permissible rate of levy for promotion purposes from 20c to $1 per pig. The amendment relates only to the maximum rate of levy, not to the operative rate of levy paid by producers. It is set by regulation. A levy has been paid by pig producers since 1975 to provide funds for the promotion of pig meat. The promotion is funded entirely by the industry and expenditure has been increasing because of the expanding activities at wholesale, retail and consumer levels and because of rising media costs. My colleague the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) will speak about the success of these promotional activities.

SPEECH.PARA: The request for an increase in the maximum rate of levy has been made by the national body of the pig industry, the Australian Commercial Pig Producers' Federation. The Federation sought this amendment as increases in the operative rate have taken the levy to 20c which is the maximum levy currently permitted under the Act. Without this amendment there is no scope to raise the levy further and expand promotional expenditure in the future. Any subsequent increase to the operative rate requires a recommendation from the Pig Meat Promotion Advisory Committee to the Minister for Primary Industry. The Committee consults with the industry before making its recommendation to the Minister.

The Opposition welcomes this Bill. We cannot possibly oppose it as the request for it comes from the industry. I want to say a few words about the pig industry. It is largely a self-help industry which does not want handouts. It rarely approaches government. It has been disappointed with the Government's response to the pig classification issue, the meat inspection issue and other things. By and large it is an industry that has been adjusting itself to the demands being put on it. It has a particular structure. It is largely an integrated industry. It is closely related to the processing part of the industry. As I said, it is a self-help industry and one that has been going along very well indeed. If we look at the problems the pig industry has been facing in recent times, we must refer to the importation of canned ham. The Industries Assistance Commission report on this matter was tabled on 6 May. The Government received the same report on 2 February 1981. The Opposition and I made the case that the Government had plenty of information on which to make up its mind on this issue. For the life of me, I do not understand why the Government put the pig industry through so much trauma by not making a decision on this matter. I, as did many other honourable members, received letters and complaints and well-documented cases from the Australian Commercial Pig Producers' Federation, the Queensland Pork Producers' State Council, the Federated Millers and Mill Employees' Association and the National Meat Canners' Association expressing great concern about the problems being faced by the industry.

The amount of canned ham coming into this country is minimal but it is affecting the industry in more than a proportionate way. That well-known pig farmer, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) announced that he was going to discuss restraint arrangements. I do not know what that means-I will not canvass what I think it might mean-but it would have the effect of limiting imports to around 14 per cent of the Australian market. That is a level of about 800 tonnes a year in respect of the canned ham market in Australia. Overall, the canned ham market represents only a small portion of the total processed pig market in Australia. But the Government does have a long term report on prepared meat products due to be presented to it late this year and again this question will arise. In the meantime, we have this restraint arrangement. The Deputy Prime Minister said, in his Press release of 1 May, that the Government had finally decided to make up its mind about this matter, after it had abundant evidence to make up its mind. He said:

Although the Industries Assistance Commission recommended no short-term assistance, the Government considers that circumstances have changed since the IAC inquiry and that action should be taken to preserve market stability pending the Government's decision on the IAC's long-term report--

I wish the Deputy Prime Minister had told us exactly what the circumstances were that had changed. It is my view that the circumstances that have changed have been very much those whereby the processors, particularly the multinationals, Mayfair Hams and Bacon Co. and Plumrose (Aust.) Ltd, were virtually holding a gun at the Government's head because they were saying that they would get import licences and bring in supplies from overseas affiliates. For example, one of the companies which wrote to me stated:

Australian Bacon Ltd, an Adelaide based company, will be most adversely affected if the Government decision is to accept the IAC recommendation because the company is one of the largest pig suppliers to the two leading canners, Plumrose and Mayfair. These manufacturers have stated that they will import from overseas affiliates so as to remain competitive with duty free imports from Romania and Yugoslavia if no short-term assistance is provided to the industry.

The company made appropriate representations on the matter at State and Federal levels. Senator Flo Bjelke-Petersen, in her maiden question, in another place, referred to the wicked communist countries, Romania and Yugoslavia, from which we are importing canned ham. It was an issue that was causing the industry a lot of concern. The Government responded eventually, having before it all the facts. I wish to goodness the Government would tell us what the changed circumstances are and if there is a particular problem in this industry in relation to its integrated nature and whether the major processors are multinationals. If that were so a lot of the rationality of bodies such as the IAC would tend to fly out the door.

I have gathered a background to the industry. Something like 216,000 tonnes of pig meat is slaughtered in Australia each year. An amount of 10,000 tonnes of bone-in-meat is used to produce about 4,500 tonnes of canned boneless ham. The dimension of this issue is such that in 1979, 450 tonnes were imported. That is equivalent to about 1,000 tonnes of bone-in-meat, as I am sure you have calculated, Mr Deputy Speaker. About 800 tonnes was imported in 1980. Very little has been imported this year. The explanation for that could be that the retailers stockpiled lower priced ham during 1980. But imports this year could reach 1,000 tonnes. There has been about a four per cent increase in production in canned ham in 1979-80. There has been a 13 per cent increase in production in early 1980-81. Canned ham is only part of the canned meat industry which has expanded production in recent years. What I am trying to explain with these figures is that the canned ham part of the industry was the part that was expanding and was the one which, at the same time, was subjected to the threat of imports, if I may put it that way.

About 80 per cent of Australia's canned ham is produced in Victoria. The area from the northern New South Wales coast up to Toowoomba in Queensland also includes major producing centres. The pig producers, the local canners and the unions waged a very active campaign in opposition to the one importing firm, C. R. Lawrence Pty Ltd. They have also lobbied hard. I can understand why the Government was reticent to act in the face of all the lobbying that was going on. But if it had the facts before it all the time, if it had the IAC report and knew what the parameters of the issue were, there is no real reason for it not making a decision. I make no further comment except to say that the Opposition supports the Bill that is before the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support the Pig Slaughter Levy Amendment Bill 1981. This Bill has been introduced to help the pork industry increase the maximum amount it can levy up to a maximum of $1 per kilo. The scheme for promotion was established in 1975. At that time, the Pig Meat Promotion Advisory Committee was established. I wish to quote from the fifth annual report of that Committee. It consists of a representative from the Department of Primary Industry, two representatives from the Australian Commercial Pig Producers' Federation and a marketing specialist. That Committee has been very successful in its endeavours to promote the pork industry throughout Australia. Production of pig meat reached 216,000 tonnes in 1979-80. The gross value of pig slaughterings during that time is estimated at $310 million. So this industry which we are debating is no small industry. I believe that the Bill is most important because promotion is an important facet of any industry if it is to survive in our ever-competing world. The expenditure on pig meat promotion in that time was $452,000 which is an increase of $117,000 from the previous year. We can see from those figures that the industry is making a tremendous endeavour to sell all of its product.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important again to remind the House that the Commonwealth makes no contribution to the promotion fund. The industry has seen fit to stand on its own feet and establish such a fund. I believe that, as far as current Government thinking is concerned, that has been excellent for the industry because it has not had to suffer any cuts. In actual fact this Bill seeks to allow the industry to impose a promotion levy of up to $1. The Act established the Pig Meat Promotion Advisory Committee whose function is to recommend the rate of slaughter levy. I think it is important to remember that the $1 levy that this Bill seeks to allow is not necessarily spent or collected in full until the industry itself decides how much is needed for the industry to function properly as far as promotion is concerned. The initial levy was 5c in 1975. The levy was increased to 20c in 1978. This Bill now seeks to increase the levy to $1.

The request to increase the levy has come from the national body of the pig industry. I think it is important that the Government adopts most of the recommendations from the industry in respect of management and follows that practice. A recommendation to fix the levy comes from the Australian Commercial Pig Producers Federation. The Federation recommends to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) the exact amount that it feels is needed adequately to promote its product. The information that I have from the industry is that it is seeking to increase the levy by 40c to 60c. This will allow another 40c to be spent in the future. I think that the proposal in the Bill to take the levy to $1 is good in that the legislation will not have to be amended in the foreseeable future. The proposed $1 levy ought to see the industry through for a number of years. The industry will recommend to the Minister that it be allowed to collect 60c of the upper limit of $1.

The pork industry has done a great deal of advertising, most of which has been through chain stores. The industry conducted a study last year in Adelaide which indicated that the sale of pork products in Adelaide stores jumped by 239 per cent. So I think that goes to show just what a good job money collected from the levy is doing for the industry. The overall increase in sales was 96 per cent. The Pig Meat Promotion Advisory Committee has concluded that the result was so good that it should seek the increase proposed in the Bill we are now considering. The Committee intends to conduct another nationwide television program this winter. Most of the capital cities as well as the Gold Coast and Toowoomba will be included in the program. It is hoped the television program will cover 47 per cent of households throughout Australia. If that can be achieved, the program again will have been excellent. The 1982 program, with an increase in funds, is expected to cover 72 per cent of households throughout the nation. So we can see that the industry is hoping to do an excellent job in this regard.

Honourable members should have no doubt from these figures that an increase in promotion funds is more than compensated for by an increase in sales. I think that this is an important point in respect of promotion. There is no point in spending a lot of money if we do not get an increase in sales. I believe that television is an excellent medium for promotion and should be encouraged especially if enough funds are available. We have seen what other industries, particularly the beef industry, are doing in this respect.

Before commending the Bill to the House, I congratulate the Government for the recommendation that there be a voluntary quota of 800 tonnes impost on imported processed pork products. The import of canned ham has been of great concern to pork producers throughout Australia. In reply to the remarks of the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), I point out that the Government is not bound by any Industries Assistance Commission report. The Commission is an independent body set up to give reports to government and government does not necessarily have to do what it recommends. The textile industry gives recent example of a recommendation of which the Government has not necessarily taken complete note.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately.

I think it must be understood that Australian companies, as well as the odd multinational, are involved. I warn all primary producers that these are the consequences of trading with communist nations.

When the Pig Meat Promotion Committee started to promote pork in a concentrated fashion, as it did, pork accounted for something like only 4 per cent of meat sales in Australia, but the advancement, in the time that the Committee has been promoting, is incredible. So I congratulate the Committee for that. I suggest to the House that the reason the levy is sought to be increased from 20 cents to 60 cents is to enable that promotion to go on all over Australia. I can only wish it success with that. One of the reasons the Committee had great success in South Australia was because of a great concentration of advertising on television. In fact, Miss Piggy was not the only pig to star on television where, of course, she is the sex symbol of the The Muppets. It appeared that the whole promotion of pork on television was an enormous success. I suggest to people that the generally held concept of pigs being dirty animals is wrong and that pigs are in fact the cleanest of all domesticated animals. Some of the misconceptions about pork meat should also be cleared up.
—Not very clean on Anthony's farm.

—I do not know that that is altogether correct. I was reading a report in the Sydney Morning Herald headed: 'All pigs want is love'. It suggested that, because of some survey that had been conducted in the Netherlands, the Dutch had worked out that pigs love a little affection. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: Where there was a good relationship between the stockman and the pigs the average number of pigs born per sow was significantly higher than on farms where the pigs were wary of humans.
The extent of affection meted out has not been determined yet-Dr Hemsworth said that a daily friendly pat on the snout may be sufficient.

That might well be the way for Kermit to win Miss Piggy's heart. I would like to make an observation or two about the value of pork as a culinary item. We all know that pork is one of the oldest foods known to man and also one of the tastiest and best loved of all meats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Charles Lamb wrote an essay on it.

—That is right, a dissertation on roast pork. I have no doubt that the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), who has the reputation of being the greatest trencher-man in this House, would know about that. The concept of super-pork has enabled the housewife to buy a whole new range of pork cuts such as schnitzel, steaks, spare ribs, chops, roast, diced and minced pork which are all now very available, all delicious and all able to be prepared with other meats. In recent days it has been quite firmly established that today's pork, while being tender and full of protein, has larger amounts of thiamine-that is vitamin B-than any other meats, poultry or fish. Contrary to popular belief there is even a place for pork on special dishes. One hundred grams of lean pork contains fewer kilojoules than beef or lamb and the small amount of fat is more easily digested because it is less saturated than other animal fats. May I suggest to all housewives, who may or may not be listening, that if they really want to have their families healthy, well satisfied and totally appreciative of their culinary art, try a little pork.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, may I have your indulgence to suggest that the House have a general debate covering this Bill, the Companies (Fees) Bill, the Companies (Transitional Provisions) Bill, the Companies (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill, the Crown Debts Priority) Bill, the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Companies (Acquisition of Shares-Fees) Amendment Bill, the Securities Industry Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Securities Industry (Fees) Amendment Bill and the Companies and Securities (Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions) Amendment Bill (No. 2), as they are associated measures.
