SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset the Opposition proposes to move an amendment to the motion that the Companies Bill be read a second time. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not opposing the Bill, the House:

(1) expresses its concern- (a) at the Government's abdication of its responsibility to make national laws for companies and securities pursuant to the Commonwealth's own constitutional powers, and in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange in 1974 (the Rae Report);

(b) at the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission to either the Government or Parliament of the Commonwealth, or to any other single elected Government or Parliament, and

(c) that despite the inordinate delay in introducing the legislation, the Parliament of the Commonwealth has not been given an opportunity effectively to scrutinise this Bill and associated Bills and will not be able effectively to determine company law in the future under the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme;

(2) calls upon the Government in the event of the breakdown for any reason of the scheme, of which the Bill is a part, immediately to proceed to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of companies;
(3) notes that this Bill places uniformity before reform in deference to powerful vested interest groups and represents a retreat to the lowest common denominator standard of company law;
(4) calls upon the Government to expedite the establishment of an Accounting Standards Review Board, and
(5) calls upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of company law, including:
(a) the abolition of the category of 'exempt proprietary company' and the privileges associated with it;

(b) the provision of statutory directions and powers to the National Companies and Securities Commission and the courts to look behind the corporate entity in appropriate circumstances, to ascertain those who control it or hold shares in it, and, having regard to the purpose of the creation of the corporate entity and the manner of its control, to affix personal liability and adjudicate personal rights where it is just and equitable to do so;
(c) the extension of the powers of inspection of the National Companies and Securities Commission to ensure the fullest reasonable access of the Commission to books;
(d) the amendment of any provision which enables questionable practices to be hidden by means of legal professional privilege;
(e) the requirement for all companies to raise and maintain a prescribed minimum nominal and paid up capital;
(f) rationalisation of the cumbersome provisions in respect of company names on the basis of single nationwide registration;
(g) a requirement that companies disclose all donations for political purposes;
(h) a requirement that dividends be paid only from the genuine profits of a company;
(i) full review of the provisions relating to fund-raising and prospectuses to ensure maximum disclosure and to require independent valuation of assets exchanged for isssued shares;
(j) reform of the provisions relating to companies financing dealings in their own shares, including the removal of the exemption given to financial assistance to salaried directors;
(k) provision for a higher required standard of competence, care and diligence for directors and officers of companies;
(l) a requirement that more frequent accounts be lodged by companies listed on the stock exchanges;

(m) in order to protect creditors and to assist the prevention of tax avoidance, the imposition of stringent disclosure requirements upon companies acting as trustees of trading trusts, in relation to their capacity as trustees and the accounts of the relevant trusts, and the imposition of heavy penalties for non-compliance;
(n) full disclosure to the public of the beneficial ownership of all shares in companies;
(o) published accounts to include full details of each director's and officer's remuneration and right of inspection for employees and shareholders of director's service contracts;

(p) adequate remedies for oppresive conduct, including extension of the concept of oppression to single and anticipated acts unfairly prejudicial to a shareholder; and provision of further means such as a 'Shareholders' Tribunal' to protect the interests of minority shareholders, and
(q) complete reform of the winding up provisions, including greater protection for unsecured creditors, following a reference on insolvency to the Australian Law Reform Commission'.

The Opposition has moved this amendment because it remains convinced that the co-operative companies and securities scheme is unsatisfactory and because the Companies Bill which forms a part of the scheme is deplorably inadequate. We have chosen, however, not to seek formal amendments to the Bill because to do so would, under the tedious arrangements of the co-operative scheme, lead to further delays in the establishment of a uniform companies code. Already, the delays have been incredible, and the passage of these Bills will not be the end of that. The States still have to enact their application legislation, so that there is no prospect for the code to be commenced before January 1982. In this context, it must be remembered that the proposal to establish a uniform companies code was first agreed to by a meeting of State and Commonwealth Attorneys-General in 1959. Moreover, it has been seven years since the Australian Labor Party sought to establish through its National Companies Bill a realistic national companies code.

Why have we waited and wasted these past seven years? Certainly, it has not resulted in a more modern, more comprehensive, or a more effective law being developed. This Bill shys away from virtually every conceivable area of reform. Its weaknesses in that respect will be dealt with in more detail later in these remarks, and also in the Committee stage. It is sufficient to record at this point that the Opposition considers this Bill to be a disgrace, all the more so for the many years that we have waited for it. But the Bill must also be considered in the context of the co-operative scheme of which it is only a part. If there could be any justification for our waiting seven years, it would be that a co-operative scheme proves to be constitutionally and practically more effective than a single national law exclusively the responsibility of this Parliament. Yet already, as the Opposition has consistently held and argued, the co-operative approach has no such superiority. The inordinate delays, for example, waiting for seven governments to reach agreement, are already testimony to one of the scheme's weaknesses. The fact that this Bill, as we have indicated in our amendment, represents the lowest common denominator of company law, is further evidence.

In previous debates on the other elements of the companies and securities package, the Opposition has clearly established that the constitutional authority, and more importantly the constitutional responsibility, for companies and securities law rests firmly with the Commonwealth. We have maintained consistently that placitum 20 of section 51 of the Constitution, which gives this Parliament power to legislate with respect to foreign corporations and trading or financial corporations formed within the limits of the Commonwealth, is a clear-cut power provided to the Commonwealth. We have enunciated the many decisions of the High Court of Australia which have clarified this power. Yet this Government, in keeping with its crippled ideology, has sought to avoid any extension of Commonwealth powers and responsibility. It has sought instead this strange hybrid, the co-operative scheme, whereby all seven governments have some say in the law, but no one of them has full responsibility for it. The excuse the Government has given for the creation of this complex mess is that, in fact, it does not have constitutional power. But that, of course, is clearly and quite demonstrably nonsense.

But what of the constitutional position of the co-operative scheme itself? Already before any of the substantive legislative codes are in operation under the scheme, a question mark hangs over it. It is like a sword of Damocles. The takeover battle by Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd earlier this year led the South Australian Corporate Affairs Commission to seek the assistance of the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission to obtain information from certain merchant banks. The response from the banks when the New South Wales body sought to comply was that it-the New South Wales CAC-was not acting in pursuit of the peace, order and good government of that State. What a farcical situation it is that a line drawn on a map of Australia by some ill-advised founding father could be such an impediment to the proper conduct of companies in Australia. So there we have it. Under this federal scheme there is, already, considerable uncertainty as to the rights and powers of one State to initiate action in another. We do not know how such a challenge would hold up in a court but, nonetheless, we have in actual experience, reason to question the constitutional validity of the scheme. Yet these seven years of delay are justified by the Government as avoiding constitutional problems. What arrant nonsense! All that the Government has avoided is its proper constitutional responsibilities.

I have dealt briefly with the problems of delay and the abdication of responsibility by the Government. I stress that of equal importance, is the contemptuous way with which the Government deals with the Parliament. As I have already indicated, no single Parliament is responsible for this co-operative law, and the National Companies and Securities Commission is not responsible to any one parliament. The Opposition considers this deplorable. I am sure, in his more rational moments that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) agrees with that. Equally, as our amendment indicates, we consider that it is lamentable that the Parliament has had no role during these seven years of delay in effectively scrutinising this Bill and the associated Bills. This is particularly regrettable given that the Parliament had such an important role, through the Rae Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange, in promoting the need for reform and national law in these areas.

I turn now to consider directly the Companies Bill and the associated Bills. Because this is a cognate debate, I must begin by indicating that the Opposition supports all of these Bills, except that we intend to oppose Part III of the Companies (Acquisition of Shares) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981. I will give further details of our objections to this part during the Committee stages, except that I should indicate here that it is a further demonstration of the extraordinary contempt that the Government has for the parliamentary process. This is because there is no intention to proclaim Part III, which effectively lifts the prohibition on crossings, until the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities unanimously agrees to do so, after investigating whether stock exchange rules adequately deal with possible conflicts of interest. That is to say, the Government is asking the Parliament to pass a law which may or may not ever be proclaimed, because neither the Government nor the Parliament yet know how adequate are the alternative means of control. This is a preposterous insult to the Parliament and to pass a law in such circumstances would be a complete abrogation of the Parliament's responsibilities. So, I have foreshadowed what our action will be in that regard.

The other Bill which requires some comment before we turn to the companies code itself, is the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill 1981. I foreshadowed that the Opposition will also be moving an amendment the motion for the second reading of this Bill. The amendment expresses our concern at the fact that the whole area of priority for the Crown remains unsatisfactory. We note that the Commonwealth, contrary to the report entitled 'Priority of Crown Debts' tabled in the Senate by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in 1978, has chosen to retain the prerogative priority of the Crown in relation to tax instalment deductions, withholding tax on dividends and interest remitted overseas. We understand that because the Commonwealth has retained its priority to this extent-a priority relating to about one-half of the total tax liability of bankrupts or companies in liquidation-the States have chosen to refuse to abrogate their own priority status.

We in the Opposition consider these actions of the Commonwealth and the States to be regrettable. We further believe that in situations of bankruptcy or liquidation, the highest priority should be afforded to the ordinary employees of the businesses concerned. I think that that is a moral judgment with which everybody should agree, not just the Opposition. Invariably, employees and those to whom compensation payments are owed are placed in the greatest hardship by business failures. The business is usually their only source of income, while most creditors and certainly the Crown have a greater spread of income sources and risks. The Opposition urges the Commonwealth Government and the States to re-examine urgently the issue of debt priorities which arise in the distribution of the assets of business in liquidation or bankruptcy.

I now turn to the Companies Bill which is the main Bill and I guess the linchpin to the whole operation. I intend to deal with particular provisions during the Committee stage and confine my remarks at this time to some general observations which reflect the attitudes of the Opposition to company law. First of all, it must be observed that this Bill is a retreat to the lowest common denominator of attitudes to company law. It has achieved the objective of uniformity, as any Bill under the scheme does, but it has totally ignored the need for reform. I think any independent observer of the corporate scene in Australia would agree that this area of corporate concern is in great need of reform. This is so, not only against a high standard of modern corporate rule but also against the standard set in earlier drafts of this legislation and against the standard reached in 1974 in the Labor Government's National Companies Bill.

The only substantial changes-I hesitate to refer to them as 'reforms'-are the substantial revision of the structure and level of penalties and completely new provisions in relation to the registration of priority of charges. These are supplemented by various minor changes which are generally worthwhile but, in relation to most areas in need of reform, a giant step backwards from previous drafts is evidenced. This backward step, I might say, appears to have been the result of pressure from powerful but minority vested interest groups. It certainly has not resulted from pressure from the thousands of small shareholders, small creditors and employees whose lives and livelihoods are so significantly affected by company law. The establishment of a new administration and a new law in relation to companies should have been seen as an opportunity to assess the role of company law from first principles. We regret that that opportunity was not undertaken.

The importance of the corporate entity in our society cannot be overstated. More and more, companies and trusts are being formed to conduct business and, regrettably, for other purposes including the avoidance of tax. So it is vitally important that in framing companies laws we keep in mind the objectives which we have. I suspect that the present Government's only objective has been uniformity, which in itself is worthwhile, but it does not in any way go to the heart of the issue. For instance, why should anyone be given the privilege of conducting business under circumstances of limited liability? Can anyone answer that with a positive response? The answer, surely, is that the modern corporation and the modern small business company provide an efficient vehicle for the mobilisation of risk capital. This modilisation has been a vital engine of economic development in the Western world.

This role of the privileges of limited liability in the corporate form carries with it a responsibility which must be exercised and be seen to be exercised. In the modern era, where corporations can be vast and where there are hundreds of thousands of small companies, the rules of the game must be uniform, clear and comprehensive. This Bill fails miserably on every one of those descriptions. The essential requirements include the imposition of a standard of skill, care and diligence appropriate to the high degree of responsibility which directors and other officers must accept. This Bill fails in this respect because it essentially reproduces the requirement which has long proven to be inadequate in the antiquated laws which we have inherited. I regret the fact that there was some evidence of reform in this area in the draft exposure Bill of some months ago which has now disappeared.

Another essential requirement is disclosure; but, once again, this Bill fails because it has constrained the powers of the NCSC. It retains such categories as 'exempt proprietary companies' with their lesser disclosure requirements and retreated from the urgent need to impose disclosure requirements on companies acting as trustees of trading trusts. I am sure that my colleague the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) has some very pointed observations to make on that subject. But these are just some of the failures of this Bill. Several others are referred to in the amendment that I have moved.

To take the example of trading trusts, we have here a classic instance of a tail-tax avoidance by private business-wagging a dog, that is, carrying on a business with a proper legal structure. Typically we have in these cases the complete abrogation of all of the fundamental responsibilities which should be imposed in circumstances of limited liability. Formally, management of the business is vested not in the directors, but in the company itself. The directors avoid their responsibilities; the companies are typically under-capitalised; and creditors and employees are left virtually without protection. The only beneficiaries are the sharp operators who seek tax benefits in company-trust combinations. This is a clear example of what I mean when I say that, in framing company law, we must have our objectives in mind. Where a business structure does not serve our objectives, it should not be allowed to form. At a very minimum, full public disclosure of the facts of each case should be required. Disclosure, if it is to be effective, must also be in such a form that it can be trusted and interpreted. Everyone knows that companies can often decide each year what profits they will disclose. Accounting standards in Australia are entirely inadequate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What utter nonsense.

—The honourable member for North Sydney thinks that is nonsense. I would suggest that the silk from Northern Sydney should go and have a look at the list of bankruptcies that litter the history of corporations in Australia and the enormous disasters that have been foist upon innocent people, be they shareholders, creditors or employees. The Opposition has repeatedly called for the establishment of a statutory body to review accounting standards. The proposal is resisted by those who work the current system. Obviously, of course they would resist it. It has been tossed about between the Ministerial Council and the National Companies and Securities Commission but, if anything, the signs are that it will never be implemented. Here again the Government is an abject failure. It is not having a very good fortnight.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, in the time that remains, I mention that the Bill also fails to deal with some of the more important new concerns which have emerged in relation to company law. Small shareholders regrettably have not been given any significant new roles in the management of companies, despite the continuation of nineteenth century concepts of the duties of directors. The divorcement of small shareholders from the affairs of companies remains total and complete. Employees continue to be ignored. There is no legislative recognition of the rights or responsibilities of employees insofar as company management is concerned. Provisions relating to employees gaining shareholdings in companies as part of their remuneration package are inadequately dealt with. There is not only no consideration of these aspects but also there is no protection afforded employees through disclosure requirements appropriate to them-despite the fact, and I will admit this, that some more progressive companies have voluntarily chosen to prepare reports to employees-and there is virtually no limit on the allocation of 'perks' to directors and others irrespective of the position of workers. The Government has ignored the employee in this Bill and shows no sign of ever waking up to the fact that social awareness and economc conditions increasingly require that employees be taken into account.

In conclusion, the Opposition will support the passage of these Bills but only because it is concerned that they be no further delayed-the Government has made a high art form of delaying these things; there has been a 22 year delay between 1959 and 1981-and because the uniformity of law which they offer is preferable to the costly inefficiencies of the current system. We believe that the Bills presented to this Parliament are utterly inadequate. Whilst the current Minister is the fourth to have had responsibility for them, he must be ashamed to have been the one who had to introduce them. The Opposition hopes that the National Companies and Securities Commission will prove more diligent and more effective in promoting company law reform than the four Ministers of this Government have proven so far to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dean Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment moved by the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) is unacceptable because it is really based on one concept, that is, that this Parliament should be unilaterally making laws relating to corporations for application throughout the whole of Australia rather than adopting a co-operative approach, which the Government has done in the package of legislation before us this evening and in legislation already passed. Really, it comes down to this: Does the national Parliament ride rough-shod over the States? Does it ignore the fact that practically and constitutionally the States have had the carriage of company law since Federation? Does it ignore the fact that not all wisdom resides with the Commonwealth or that there ought, indeed, to be true co-operation as between the Commonwealth and the States on such important pieces of legislation?

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members on this side of the House adopt the view that there ought to be a co-operative approach and that the Commonwealth ought not to ride rough-shod over the rights of the States, including the State of New South Wales. We adopt the view that this Parliament ought to take account of and, where necessary, learn from the experience of the States, which practically and constitutionally have had the carriage of corporate legislation since Federation. The amendment moved by the honourable member for Parramatta is unacceptabble because he does not want to take that into account. He wants this Parliament to ride rough-shod over the States. That is not something that honourable members on this side of the House will countenance. We will even take account of what Mr Wran and his colleagues have to say and go ahead with the co-operative package accordingly.

The honourable member for Parramatta made great reference to delays. Of course, if it is decided as a matter of principle that there ought to be co-operation with the States, regrettably some delays will be unavoidable. Nevertheless, we have already passed some parts of the total package of companies legislation. We have before us this evening the Companies Bill and its associated legislation, all of which brings to a climax a co-operative approach bringing about real uniformity in this area for Australia for the first time. That is in fact a monumental piece of progress. This package of legislation is a major feat of all governments in this nation. It involves probably some 50 Bills being passed by the parliaments of Australia. It is the largest legislative undertaking ever taken on by a Commonwealth government. It certainly represents a major step forward in providing uniform legislation through which much of Australia's commerce and business can be carried on. It is also worth noting that some of the delays referred to by the honourable member for Parramatta have been caused by the fact that the legislation has been given out for public exposure. I think that it is rather a good thing that the government of the day not only co-operates with the States in framing this legislation but also exposes draft legislation to the public at large so as to get back comment on it and tries to improve and amend the legislation as a result of that.

The final point that we should come to in talking about the legislation is that in future amendments between the Commonwealth and the States will be done on a majority basis. Now that uniform agreement has been achieved with the States we are in a situation where the foundation has been laid for continued uniformity and co-operation in the companies area as between the Commonwealth and the States. In other words, the package we have this evening and the packaging already passed by this Parliament lay the foundation-a very firm foundation-for continued reform in the companies area. The honourable member for Parramatta referred to a lot of problems that he sees in the Bill. The problems are either real-there may well be some that are real-or imaginary. The honourable member has a very fertile imagination. Whatever happens in practice, at least we now have the foundation whereby we can learn from experience. On the foundation of this co-operative package of legislation we can consider amendments and co-operatively the nation will continue, where necessary, to reform companies legislation. To say, therefore, that in this package of legislation the Government has shied away from real reform or has abrogated its constitutional responsibility is to ignore the fact that reform has been undertaken and that the foundation has now been laid in co-operation with the States for further reform as we gain experience from the enactment of this legislative package.

My further comments this evening will be related to the Companies Bill itself. Whilst I do not ignore the fact that there are important matters in all the other Bills in this package, for the remainder of my comments I will address myself to the Companies Bill because it is probably the major piece of legislation in the package before us tonight. Probably the most important concept that the new Companies Bill incorporates is the provision for one place registration within Australia for companies. Before going on to that in further detail it is probably worthwhile to go back a little in history to give an understanding of precisely what we have before us this evening and where it comes from. In December 1978 the Commonwealth and all six States executed a formal agreement to proceed with the preparation and enactment of uniform legislation in the companies area. That formal agreement contained four essential elements. Firstly, it formalised the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities comprised of one Minister representing each State and the Commonwealth. The Council was to reach unanimous agreement on all initial legislation, as we have it before us this evening. Subsequent amendments require only majority approval. The second element--

TALK.START.PARA: —I am with you old son.

—I am glad to hear it. The second element is agreement to establish the National Companies and Securities Commission. The NCSC is subject to the direction of the Ministerial Council established by the formal agreement. The NCSC, subject to that direction, will administer the legislation under the scheme. It has various powers including powers to hold hearings, summon witnesses and delegate most of its powers and functions to the State and Territory corporate affairs officers. Thirdly, the formal agreement provides for maximum use of existing State and Territory corporate affairs officers. Although the legislation gives all powers and functions to the NCSC, the use of existing officers will ensure a decentralised administration of the scheme. The fourth element concerns a legislative framework which involves the States adopting the scheme legislation when it is placed in the Australian Capital Territory. The Australian Capital Territory will be the first to pass all this legislation, which is then to be adopted by the States and the Territory. Subsequent amendments to the legislation passed by this Parliament will automatically apply in the other jurisdictions. Therefore, we have a Companies Bill coming before us as part of that total framework established by the formal agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: One place registration of companies has fairly obvious advantages as far as companies and all professions associated with them are concerned. A company can achieve nationwide recognition without the need to lodge company documents in other States or Territories. Overseas corporations will similarly have to seek registration in only one place. Associated with that measure is the fact that incorporated in the Companies Bill is a national system of registration for auditors and liquidators and, indeed, one winding-up of any corporation in all participating jurisdictions. In that respect, I refer the House to clause 420 of the Bill. That is one but probably the most significant of the modifications or innovations incorporated within this Companies Bill, but there are others. This Bill contains a rationalisation of penalties and sanctions. A close examination of those penalties and sanctions will show that the Companies Bill has teeth which are not so blunt, as is sometimes made out. The new Companies Bill has new powers of inspection which represent a dramatic improvement in the present position of companies Acts within the States themselves.

I refer the House to the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore). The powers of inspection are referred to in some detail on page 52. The limited powers of inspection in the present main States companies Acts are not expressed in a way that enables them to be used to investigate suspected criminal activity. In addition, they do not enable a corporate affairs office to obtain the information and explanations needed to explain the records inspected. If inquiries do not produce voluntary co-operation a corporate affairs office either has to abandon the case or request a special investigation, with all the ramifications that that entails. It was considered in the formulation of this Companies Bill that those powers were inadequate. Therefore the Bill contains new powers of inspection which address themselves to some of the weaknesses that I have mentioned.

Significant reform is contained in the new Companies Bill in relation to pre-incorporation contracts. There has been some criticism that clause 81 of the Companies Bill does not effect any significant reform relating to contracts entered into prior to a company's formation. The question might have been asked: Why does the Bill not make personally liable, in the absence of an express agreement to the contrary, a person who purportedly entered into a contract in the name of or on behalf of the company, as might be seen in other codes? The object of clause 81 is certainly to modify the existing highly unsatisfactory common law position relating to pre-incorporation contracts. Under present law a company cannot effectively ratify pre-incorporation contracts so as to sue or to be sued on them. Under present law it is difficult to attach legal obligations of pre-incorporation contracts to promoters or other individuals purporting to act for companies. Clause 81 provides that a company, not formed at the time a contract was entered into, will be able later to ratify the contract so as to be bound by and entitled to the benefit of it. Under sub-clause 4 a person purporting to contract for the non-existent company will be personally liable in damages in some circumstances. There is a good basis for the modification to be expressed in this way, based largely on a 1979 report of the Victorian Law Reform Commissioner.

The new Companies Bill contains substantial modifications to the provisions in general about shareholdings. I will not have time this evening to go into those matters in detail. Perhaps my colleague, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), will be able to do so. In relation to priority of charges, the new Bill ensures that there is a system of priorities in accordance with the recommendations of the Eggleston report. That system of priorities has been included as a substitute for earlier requirements that charges be registered within a certain time of creation, usually 30 days. In addition, the present Bill seeks to refine those priority provisions beyond those contained in the August 1980 draft. Another major change from the August draft is the removal of the sixth Schedule. That Schedule, which related to companies' accounts and group accounts, was similar to the old ninth Schedule in the Interstate Corporate Affairs Commission Companies Acts. The provision now is for the sixth Schedule requirements relating to accounts and group accounts to be made into regulations.

Some critics have said that this is unreasonable in that it might permit draconian amendments to be the regulations at a later time. But, on the other hand, by ensuring that these requirements can be enacted in regulation, the Parliament retains flexibility so that where deficiencies arise and where changes are found to be necessary they can be made more speedily and effectively than if an amendment to a Schedule were to be enshrined in an Act. It should be borne in mind also that the regulations are intended to take the same form substantially as the draft Schedule 6 or the old Schedule 9. To this date they contain no significant departure from the present law. As I said at the beginning, it should be remembered that this is a foundation for the future administration of company law in this nation. Where deficiencies arise and where changes are required the Ministerial Council and the parliaments of this nation should be prepared swiftly and effectively to make the changes necessary.

Some concern has been expressed about provisions relating to the duties of directors. Such provisions in the August Bill appear to have been removed. Questions have been raised as to why there are not more significant changes relating to directors' duties. The principal provision relating to directors' duties is clause 229, and it is certainly wider than the existing main States legislation. It applies to all officers of a company, not just directors. Directors and other officers are required to exercise a reasonable degree of care in performing their duties, in addition to the present requirement of reasonable diligence. The requirement that officers do not make improper use of information obtained by virtue of their position has been extended to cover former officers and employees. Provision has been made also for more severe penalties, involving terms of imprisonment. But, certainly, the present Bill does not impose a duty of skill on directors as was done in an earlier draft of the Bill. This change has been made in the light of public submissions received. Those submissions are to the effect that, firstly, it is not appropriate to impose an objective standard of skill on directors since they are employed in different capacities, for different purposes and with the expectation that they will contribute different skills. The test imposed unrealistic burdens on outside directors. Practice might show that those provisions are not severe or extensive enough. But surely it is desirable, having established this co-operative framework and having arrived at the terms of this co-operative Bill, to get it moving, to see it work and then to decide whether weaknesses need to be corrected or changes ought to be made. To imagine what may not in real trading practice come about is folly. I intended to spend a little time on the trading trust provisions and the excitement stirred up by one national newspaper recently when it suggested that the so-called tax lobby had won a major concession by having them removed. From all my inquiries I found that newspaper report to be quite erroneous. The changes were not the result of any so-called tax lobby; rather they were the result of further consideration by the Ministerial Council. I hope that my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney will have time to address himself more fully to that aspect of the matter.

Finally, I refer to some Press criticism that the disclosure provisions in this Bill as they might relate to Australian operations or the operations within Australia of overseas corporations do not go far enough. I simply draw the attention of the House to the provisions of clauses 561 and 540 and the appeal provisions of 537. The legislative package that we have before us is but a foundation for the future advanced and uniform administration of company law in this nation. It is a tremendous step forward. It is a monumental feat of government and it ought to be enacted without any further delay. It is to be applauded by Australian business.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I support this companies legislation, it is with pleasure that I second the amendment. This package of Bills that purports to regulate business corporations can be bluntly described as law by the privileged for the privileged and of the privileged. It does nothing more than perpetuate the existing inadequate regulation of business corporations. If the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) were honest, the appropriate title of the Companies Bill would be the Companies' Directors Protection Bill. I repeat what I said in regard to earlier legislation: This legislation can be summed up in two brief sentences-if one is an honest investor, beware; if one is a market or company shark, it will be business as usual.

SPEECH.PARA: I challenge the Minister to indicate the corporate reforms that are so clearly needed to ensure security and protection to both corporations and the community. Where is the embodiment of the so-called complete reappraisal of the role of the company in society? Companies, institutions and organisations must be responsive to the community. This has become important, although it is difficult because of rapid political, economic, technological and social changes. The community has developed new and obviously greater expectations. Business corporations have suffered a considerable downturn in credibility over the last two decades, for a variety of reasons.

Company law must establish a solid framework which defines a company's responsibility to its shareholders, creditors and the society. Beyond quesion the coming decade will bring ever-increasing pressure to bear; it will test these laws to the limit. Regrettably, these Bills fail to meet the test. They will be inadequate and, as a consequence, ineffective. One can only describe them as completely outmoded. Even worse, they serve as nothing more than a charter for the unscrupulous. This so-called revamped companies law is almost the same as that in the laissez-faire Britain of the nineteenth century. Where are the profound and meaningful changes? Members of companies, particularly large companies, take little part in company affairs. Those members are poorly placed, and the provisions in these bills make sure that shareholders do not receive the information about their companies which would enable them to act as watchdogs on management. A classic example of that is the collapse of Associated Securities Ltd. Nothing in this legislation will remedy that situation. It is an indictment of all those who claim responsibility for these Bills.

There are no real changes to the legislation; changes which are so necessary if the corporate sector is to fulfil its responsibility in our complex society. For instance, it is essential that proxy voting be used for shareholders unable to attend meetings. I hope the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender), who is to follow me in this debate, will explain where that is provided for in the Companies Bill. There should be mandatory use of two-way proxies for important resolutions to provide a means for shareholders' participation and protection. There is not a word about that in the Bill. Why not? There are good reasons for it. We will come to that at the Committee stage. Creditors of limited liability companies will receive little protection from these laws. Unlike companies in Europe, Australian companies do not have to have a prescribed minimum paid up capital. There is no stringent regulation of the issue of shares for non-cash consideration. In that respect the legislation is utterly defective. There is no prohibition on the payment of dividends to shareholders if some or all of the share capital has been lost or the revenue losses have been incurred in the immediately preceding year. There is not a word about it. What a fraud the legislation is. In Australia the law-this legislation perpetuates it-permits a limited liability company to be formed with a share capital of 2c. Public companies must have a share capital of at least 5c. One may well ask whether this is a ridiculously low price to pay for the advantage of corporate status and limited liability. Certainly the plethora of $2 companies that the public all too frequently hears about tends to breed cynicism and contempt towards the corporate sector. It is scandalous. In short, limited liability status is not a privilege to be earned but a licence to be abused. The fact that most companies may not abuse the licence is no answer to the claim that our laws are recklessly permissive.

I refer to some of the appalling deficiencies in the legislation. Firstly, there is a lack of creditor protection, an absence of minimum issue capital requirements, failure to regulate non-cash consideration share issues, failure to designate properly the funds from which dividends may be paid, failure to require all limited liability companies to make public audited annual accounts and failure to abolish exempt proprietary companies, which was done in Britain in 1967. I ask honourable members to contrast that with the Australian position, and to consider the situation in West European countries such as West Germany, Sweden, the United Kingdom and the European Economic Community countries. Secondly, there is failure to provide adequate protection to shareholders and failure to regulate new share issues so that existing shareholders are treated fairly. There is not a word in the legislation about pro rata issues and issues for non-cash consideration. There is also failure to remove the manifest weakness in the current section 186 of the Companies Act which in limited circumstances allows shareholders to seek judicial relief from the unfair conduct of the company's management or controlling shareholders. The honourable member for North Sydney agrees with that. I refer him to section 75 (1) of the United Kingdom Act of 1980. Thirdly, our companies laws have failed to deal with the fundamental weaknesses, which have been an affront for decades and there are separate State laws. There are problems for pacesetter States. Taking the lead to reform legislation could result in companies setting up operations in other jurisdictions. It has been done time after time. That could lead to a possible loss of State revenue and employment. Is this good company law? It is defective company law. Contrast that with the sensible positions that apply throughout the laws of the EEC countries. It is bad, lowest common denominator legislation. We are locking ourselves into a structure which by its very nature can only create weak and ineffective laws when clearly strong laws are needed.

A number of examples of that include the situation of exempt propriety companies. Most Australian limited liability companies are, within the existing Companies Act, defined as exempt propriety companies. Essentially, such a company is a propriety company in which no member of the public has direct or indirect interest in its shareholding. At least 90 per cent of Australian limited liability companies come within that definition. Such a company does not have to have its accounts audited annually. Its accounts can be audited but a copy of its audited balance sheet does not have to be filed with the Corporate Affairs Commission. Consequently, a creditor of such a company cannot search any public file for evidence of the credit worthiness of the company concerned. It is a scandal. The company does not have to pay for the privilege of limited liability by making adequate public disclosures of its financial position. If such a company does not have its accounts audited each year it must file a copy of its unaudited balance sheet with the Corporate Affairs Commission. Obviously, creditors rely on unaudited statements at their peril. The exempt propriety company concept was derived from the United Kingdom. In 1962 the English Jenkins committee on company law reform recommended that the concept be abolished and rightly so. Why did it do that? It took the view that such companies should have their accounts and balance sheets audited professionally each year, and for such accounts and balance sheets to be made public. They ought to be. Creditors of all such companies have a right to accurate information concerning their credit worthiness. The 1967 United Kingdom Companies Act abolished such companies, without creating any significant practical problems. Nothing better illustrates the gross inadequacy of Australian company law than the fact that the vast majority of such limited companies are entitled to secrecy in regard to their financial affairs.

I now turn to dividends out of profits, which is referred to in clause 565 of the Companies Bill and section 376 of the current Act. Neither the current Act nor the Bill defines profits. That is a scandal. Consequently, as under the existing section 376 (1), a company could lose most of its share capital through trading losses and then in a particular accounting period make a profit. That profit could be used for dividend purposes under this clause without the previous losses first being made good. It is scandalous. It is ironic that the United Kingdom has adopted a more stringent definition of profits. Section 39 (1) of the United Kingdom Act states:
(1) A company shall not make a distribution . . . except out of profits available for the purposes . . .

(2) For the purpose of this part . . . a company's profit available for distribution, are its accumulated realised profits, so far as not previously utilised by distribution or capitalisation, less its accumulative or realised losses, so far as not previously written off in a reduction or re-organisation of capital duly made.
Section 40 of the United Kingdom Act states:
A public company may only make a distribution at any time:
(a) if at that time the amount of its net assets is not less than the aggregate of the companies called up share capital and its undistributable reserves; and
(b) if, and to the extent that, the distribution does not reduce the amount of those assets to less than that aggregate.

Let us look at this Bill and what it does not do. It fails to make it difficult for a limited company to be formed. There are no minimum issued capital requirements-for instance, the requirement of a minimum of $50,000 in issued capital for public companies as is the case in the United Kingdom. That requirement is contained in the 1980 Act. The Australian Bill fails to strengthen the extraordinarily weak regulation of share issues for non-cash consideration. I will take up that matter with the sick at the back, the honourable member for North Sydney, in Committee. There is no requirement in the Bill that non-cash consideration should be expertly and independently valued and reported upon as is the case in the United Kingdom Companies Act, thus off-setting State cash transaction techniques for avoiding the limited disclosure of non-cash issues under proposed section 113 of the new legislation. This opening has not been closed off are recommended by the Eggleston Committee in 1970. Under this Bill the position remains exactly as it was.

There is no early warning device should there be a significant loss of share capital. Again, such a provision is contained in section 34 of the United Kingdom Act. There is no attempt to ensure that shareholders should receive equal and fair entitlements to new shares issued by companies. They ought to be protected. There is no attempt to enlarge the opportunities for minority shareholders to challenge the validity of acts of the board of directors or the general meeting. There is not a word on this matter in the Bill. I now read section 75 of the United Kingdom companies Act.

(1) A member of a company may apply to the Court by petition for an order under this section on the ground that the affairs of the company are being or have been conducted in a manner which is unfairly prejudicial to the interests of some part of the members (including at least himself) or that some actual or proposed act or omission . . . is or would be prejudicial.''

Perhaps the honourable member for North Sydney would be kind enough to explain to me where there is a provision in the Bill that gives protection. I challenge him to show me. In contrast to these necessary provisions which are operative throughout Western Europe, this Bill provides for a small privileged section-that is, company directions-the protection they neither warrant nor deserve. All other needs and protection are subjugated to these privileged few.

Why is the Bill so weak? The contents of the Bill were supposed to reflect closely the existing Interstate Corporate Affairs Commision legislation. That legislation was weak, for a number of obvious reasons. To add to the problem, the weak laws were not even uniform. The new State-Commonwealth co-operative venture may in the short term solve the uniformity problems, but it certainly will not result in significantly stronger laws. It is highly questionable whether uniform weak laws are better than divergent laws, some of which are progressive. Let me repeat that: It is highly questionable whether uniform weak laws are better than divergent laws, some of which are progressive.

The reasons strong new laws are unlikely are: Firstly, the initial legislation requires unanimous consent by all members of the Ministerial Council; and, secondly, the amendments are unlikely unless they are acceptable to the Ministerial Council. The agreement provides for amendments being approved by a mere majority vote. However, any dissenting member or members may threaten to leave the scheme unilaterally should these amendments be pressed home. Such action would ruin the scheme. Such a threat would be taken seriously with the result that planned majority reforms will be either jettisoned or watered down. This sort of compromise legislation is not what this country needs to lift its companies legislation out of the backwaters of the advanced Western world.

What is the answer? The dual goals of, firstly, uniform legislation and, secondly, strong legislation can be achieved only by the Commonwealth Government using its constitutional powers to pass laws relating to the formation of trading and financial corporations. Such laws would apply uniformly throughout Australia. They must be stronger laws than those contained in this package of Bills because the Commonwealth Government would not have to satisfy State governments. It would have the power to pass legislation thought necessary. It would be politically accountable for its legislation in a way that is completely absent from this co-operative venture. There is no direct political accountability in this legislation. This is admitted on both sides of the chamber. Rather, it is defused between all the members of the Ministerial Council. Surely strong uniform law is preferable to uniform but compromise law. If strong uniform law can be achieved by Commonwealth legislation, the onus is on those supporting the alternative approach to demonstrate clearly that it will work in practice. The evidence so far available suggests it will not.

Australia cannot afford to play around with company law for another decade as it has done over the last decade. Time will not permit that leeway. We all agree on the desperate need to maximise Australian investment and to minimise the appalling escalation of foreign investment. If we are to maintain that which is rightfully ours, such laws must be effective. They must provide the atmosphere to induce people to invest with security. They must be just to all, not selective as this legislation clearly is.

If we place on the statute book laws that are weak, fragmented and inadequate, laws that fail to give shareholders and creditors in the community the protection and the security needed, laws which fail to make directors and auditors both responsible and accountable, that give one section immunity and leave the rest vulnerable, we have failed to meet the test. We have failed to provide the strong framework which is so necessary if business corporations and the investing public are to operate in a secure and expanding market.

These Bills will provide laws which will do nothing more than has been done since the inception of legislation in this area. They will provide a breeding ground for the spiv, the charlatan and the corporate crook. They were eliminated in Europe a decade ago. It is a scandal that the so-called law makers of this country perpetuate ineffective law. But then, after all, we do not put gentlemen in gaol.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—That is no joke. I ask the honourable member for North Sydney to tell me how many knights of the realm of Associated Securities Ltd the Government has put in gaol. It is not likely to do so. I ask the honourable member to tell me also in the Committee stage of the Bill where the provision is in this legislation which will put those gentlemen behind bars? The legislation does not provide for that. What is needed is strong, uniform and national laws passed by the Commonwealth which are accountable to the people in exactly the same way as our taxation laws.

SPEECH.PARA: I trust that before the debate is concluded tonight we will have a chance to deal extensively with a number of issues that have been raised by the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) and that I wish to raise at the Committee stage. It will be an outrage if the Government attempts to gag the debate of this Bill at 10.30 this evening. That is what it intends to do. It is with pleasure that I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a subject which is as complex as this, it is very easy for people to have differing views about certain aspects. We are, after all, talking about the most comprehensive and complex single package of legislation ever to be put before this House. If the differing views were genuine, one would think they would be expressed in terms of some reasoned argument rather than as assertions which have at the bottom of them that sort of whining, latent hatred of anything that has to do with business. Let us look for one or two minutes at some of the matters raised in the motion which has been moved by the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) and seconded by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi). If they were genuine--
—We call it an amendment.

—I thank the honourable gentleman. If they were genuine in what they were saying, we would see some serious matters in their amendment to the motion. However, let us look at one or two of the things which were said and consider, firstly, whether they are serious and, secondly, whether they have any support at all. Reference is made in paragraph (5) (b) of the amendment, in the convoluted language which is employed, to some power in the Commission to ascertain those who control or own shares in the company. The paragraph states further:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . having regard to the purpose of the creation of the corporate entity and the manner of its control, to affix personal liability and adjudicate personal rights where it is just and equitable to do so;

That is what courts have been doing for a long time. The honourable member raised the question at the end of his peroration: 'Tell me about any crooks in effect who have gone to gaol?' I will tell the honourable member about two such persons who went to gaol as a result of an investigation into an organisation called Gollan Holdings which, until its crash, was the largest trading company in Australia. I carried out that investigation and, as a consequence, the managing director went to gaol for 13 years and the financial director went to gaol for 12 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not enough; he should have got more.
—Those are exceedingly long prison terms, gentlemen; you cannot avoid that. This is an illustration of the effective use of the powers of special investigations.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to deal now with one or two other matters which were raised in this amendment. Paragraph (5) sub-paragraph (g) states:
a requirement that companies disclose all donations for political purposes;

Of course, that is the old call no doubt inspired by instructions from the Premier of New South Wales. Does that have anything to do with company law? Of course it does not! It has something to do with politics and the political objectives of those on the other side of the House. I turn now to another provision which was referred to in paragraph (5) (c) of the amendment which states:
the extension of the powers of inspection of the National Companies and Securities Commission to ensure the fullest reasonable access of the Commission to books;

If honourable gentlemen had examined the provisions in the Act relating to special investigations, and, as I have, had conducted two major special investigations, if they had seen that the provisions that now appear are in fact wider than they have ever been, and if they understood the truly draconic nature of a special investigation, they would not be putting to this House a proposition which either they know to be false or they do not really care whether it is true or false because it expresses a point of view-which is their point of view-that businessmen are the manipulators. We heard honourable members say tonight that businessmen manipulate company accounts. We heard it said that those directors are a small privileged sector, the people who bring the country down, whereas the truth of the matter is that they are the people who have built the country up.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the workers? Have they done anything?
—The honourable member asks: 'What about the workers?' The workers from that side of the fence do not do very much around here.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at some of the other Alice in Wonderland assertions that have been made by some honourable members on the other side of the chamber. Firstly, we are told that there has been a delay of seven years and two of those years they were in power. Then we are told that there has been a delay from 1959 to 1981 during which they had a period in power. Lastly we get a period of 10 years. That complete overlooking and that desire to put to one side anything which is against them, illustrate the genuineness of the complaints that they have made.

The honourable member for Herbert (Mr Dean) stated that this was a most comprehensive package of legislation. Indeed, it certainly is. I said earlier that in legislation which was as wide, as complex and as embracing as this legislation is, unquestionably there are areas where one can differ. But what is not conceded by the Opposition is that there is anything good in this legislation whereas in truth it represents a most revolutionary attempt in this country to put forward legislation relying upon a joint Federal-State scheme and co-operation between the States and the Federal Government in the knowledge that, if one does not engage in that kind of an exercise, one will put forward legislation which more likely than not will be struck down in parts because it would not have constitutional power to uphold it. The honourable member for Parramatta said that the Australian Labor Party asserted that there was a certain way to construe the Constitution. No doubt the Labor Party would go ahead and make that assertion to the High Court and it would lose because it is perfectly plain that it cannot maintain such a wide and comprehensive collection of legislative proposals simply under the constitutional powers which, in a divided federal system, are granted to this Government.

Let us look at some of the revolutionary aspects of this legislation. For the first time, we have a legislative scheme which embraces the entire area of companies and securities. All of this has been brought forward in one package. This is the first time this has ever taken place in this country. For the first time we find built into the legislation provision for automatic uniformity of amendments. Once they are passed by this Parliament, they flow on to the other States. This was something which was sadly lacking in the 1960 Uniform Companies Act. For the first time we find a permanent ministerial council for companies and securities which will act as a watchdog body with the task of ongoing review of legislation and general oversight and control of the implementation of this legislative scheme. For the first time we find uniform administration of a scheme and general superintendence by the National Companies and Securities Commission.

These elements are well known although the revolutionary nature of the proposals has not really been appreciated perhaps by the arguments that have been put in this House by those honourable gentlemen on the other side of the chamber. They amount in short to a fundamental change of approach to legislation in this field. The attainment of uniformity of laws and their administration, whilst in itself of great benefit, is not all that is offered by the scheme. Very much more is offered by considerable and detailed alterations that have been made to the code which is before the House. Not a great deal of public attention has been focused upon these matters. Where public attention has been focused on the Companies Act and other legislation, more often than not it has centred on those matters which are thought to be newsworthy rather than noteworthy.

I will name just four of those matters, one of which has been referred to already by the honourable member for Herbert. For the first time we have a single system of registration of companies, that is, a single incorporation concept. Once a person registers in one State, that person is not concerned with repeating the filing of accounts year in and year out in other States. Secondly, there is a capacity to transfer domiciles of companies. That is a most advantageous capacity for any businessman to have. I will give one example of why this can be deemed to be so. Assume, for example, that one has a business. One carries on that business in the State of New South Wales, through a company structure set up in that State. Let us say that one wishes to transfer that business to the sunnier climes of Queensland. Until now it has been impossible to do that. Once this Bill becomes an Act it will be possible to transfer the domicile of one's company from one State to the other so that once one transfers to the new State one is, for all purposes, regarded as domiciled in that State and the company is accepted in that State.

Let us look at something else. There is provision here for the first time for a multi-State scheme of arrangements. That is something to which neither of the Opposition members referred. What does that involve? A scheme of arrangement is simply an arrangement which is entered into between a company and its creditors. It is an arrangement which is supervised by the court. It is made pursuant to court convened meetings. Before the legislation which is presently before the House, if there were assets of a company in more than one State it was necessary to go to each State to have a separate scheme of arrangement. Not only was this highly technical, highly expensive and highly wasteful of funds that otherwise would go to creditors but also it was fraught with risk for the very simple reason that in one State the scheme might be accepted, in the next State the scheme might be accepted but in the third State it might be rejected with the consequence that the whole scheme would fail. It is now necessary to implement the scheme only in the State of incorporation; that is, the State in which the company has its home.

Lastly, I touch upon another of the improvements that have been made. I have referred to certain improvements in relation to the conduct of specal investigations. Let us look at two items there. First of all, if one looks at clause 296 (12)-honourable members opposite supposedly are interested in improvements but they seemed to be able to find none-one will find that there is a provision there which empowers the inspector, the person who is running the special investigation, to control the conduct of legal advisers appearing in front of him. This is very necessary because at times what takes place is that the legal adviser appearing on behalf of somebody who has been questioned will, by objections or by seeking to advise his client before questions are answered by his client, in effect entirely disrupts the conduct of the investigation. That is something to be avoided and it has been avoided.

In the same set of provisions we have provisions now for conditions in respect of confidentiality of the transcript of examination of witnesses. That, of course, is very necessary so that witnesses cannot pass round transcripts amongst themselves and get their stories together before they come to the inspector or before they come back to be re-examined. These are areas where the content has been altered, where the law has been improved. There are unquestionable areas where improvement can still be made. This will always be so in an area as complex as this.

Let me conclude in the time that I have left by correcting something which has been said in the Australian Financial Review and which has been referred to today in passing by the honourable member for Hawker and the honourable member for Parramatta. On 6 May 1981 on the front page of the Australian Financial Review appeared the headline 'Tax Avoidance Lobby's Big Win'. The course of the article went on to refer to trading trusts. The article stated:
The tax avoidance lobby has had a big win against the new companies legislation with a vital provision making avoidance more difficult being quietly dropped by the Federal Government.

There are two answers to that. First of all, the history of this Government has been that it has tried at all times and with considerable success to plug tax avoidance loopholes. Indeed, I would think that these could never be called tax avoidance loopholes in any event because trading trusts do not in any way facilitate avoidance in any different aspect to the way in which any other corporate vehicle works. The first point is that this Government has had a record in avoidance which is very hard to beat because it has closed the avoidance schemes. Secondly, the article entirely misconceives the history of the legislation now before the House. The exposure draft of April 1980 contained some provisions concerning trading trusts. They were complex, they were lengthy and they were dropped unanimously-I emphasise the word 'unanimously'-in August 1980. The then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs in his second reading speech stated:
A considerable number of submissions were received on these provisions-
That is to say, the trading trust provisions-

many of them critical and many raising new issues that had not been dealt with in the exposure draft. After reviewing the submissions, the Ministers unanimously agreed that further work was required to be done on this matter before any legislation could be prepared.

TALK.START.PARA: —I referred to that, too.

—The honourable member for Herbert did in fact refer to that. That should be made perfectly clear to this House. The article unfortunately and, no doubt, inadvertently proceeds upon a complete misapprehension of the basis on which the trading trust provisions were dropped from the legislation and the time when those provisions were dropped from the legislation. This was in August of last year, not just a few weeks ago.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the remarks made by honourable members on the other side of the House reveal a certain point of view. That point of view is that businessmen are never right, that businessmen are always wrong, that businessmen are crooks, and that businessmen seek to take advantage of people. That is implicit in everything that was said. It was admitted in passing that there might be some honest businessmen and it was said: 'We would like to see you build up a proper and decent capital market'. But the whole gist of the complaints was to the effect that we cannot trust them, that they will manipulate accounts, that they will manipulate people, that they will run shell companies and take benefits out of those companies, and that they will rob the poor. But we proceed upon the basis that businessmen are usually responsible people. We have imposed in this Bill a wide variety of obligations upon businessmen to maintain confidentiality, to exercise diligence, not to take advantage of information that comes to them in confidence and otherwise. We have enclosed them with a variety of obligations which are there for one purpose and one purpose only-the protection of the investing public together with the protection of those who invest in the companies.
