TALK.START.PARA: —What was needed was a truly effective national scheme based on strong, uniform legislation to regulate the companies and securities area throughout Australia into the 1980s. But what we have before us tonight is a weak excuse for the regulation of companies in Australia. It is a great pity that so little has come from so much talk, so much time and so much effort. Whilst the Opposition does not oppose this legislation, we are nevertheless reluctant to support these Bills which do not enact substantial reform. Clearly there has been a great need for effective reform in the areas of companies legislation and the Australian securities markets from the time of the Poseidon boom in the 1960s. If we are to believe the optimistic economic assessments of the Fraser Government that Australia is on the brink of a new resources boom in the 1980s then it should be even more important at this time to ensure that effective reform has been implemented. The general public has a right to be protected from the shady practices that we saw in the 1960s and the 1970s. The greatest need in relation to companies and the securities industry is for provisions which ensure effective public accountability.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Rae report of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchanges in 1974 has provided us with detailed evidence of some of the worst features of company practice. It also provided us with very strong recommendations on the need for a national scheme to regulate the activities of the Australian securities market and the related activities of companies and their directors. It is worth recalling some of the Committee's findings to remind ourselves of the importance of effective reform to overcome the massive abuses which were uncovered. Volume 1, Part 1, Section 15.1 of that report states:

We discovered numerous instances of improper practices in the making of new issues and in the distribution. There has been considerable evidence of insider trading, manipulation and other abuse in the stock markets . . .

In addition to our concern with abuses within the securities market, we are alarmed by evidence of improper, reckless and incompetent behaviour on the part of some of those in control of public companies and investment funds. The investor has too often been exploited by controllers of listed public companies and by managers of investment funds. We are alarmed by the frequency and serious nature of failures to meet appropriate standards of full accurate and timely disclosure . . .

That is what the Opposition wants reformed and that is what is not happening in this legislation. This Committee recommended the establishment of effective national regulation to overcome the glaring deficiencies uncovered during this investigation. Seven years later we are still waiting for such legislation to be developed. The Commonwealth has the constitutional power to enact legislation for this purpose. Several State governments have initiated some reforms. The general public-the small investors of Australia-have waited patiently. After all this delay one could be forgiven for expecting that the legislation presented would address itself seriously to the provisions of effective reform measures. Instead we find that we have been presented with ineffective, watered-down legislation that will be administratively very difficult to implement. This legislation relies on the concept of co-operative federalism which is a most cumbersome mechanism for implementing effective reforms. What is it, after all, we are trying to deal with? We are trying to deal with a national Australia-wide industry. There is, of course, some doubt that this Government is even interested in implementing effective reform. As the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) said in his second reading speech, this was a matter of 'fine tuning rather than reform'.

The formal agreement of December 1978 provided complicated machinery to introduce co-operative regulation of the companies and the securities industry-a Ministerial Council, a National Companies and Securities Commission, use of State administrations for implementation of the new arrangements and provision of uniform legislation. Uniform legislation is to be provided by the constitutional device of, firstly, enacting legislation for the Australian Capital Territory and then having that legislation adopted in each State. The problems associated with synchronisation of this whole unnecessary exercise have already contributed to considerable delay. Not only is this legislation extremely limited in terms of providing effective protection for the public, but also it relies for its implementation on the achievement of consensus among other States-a task likely to be more difficult than passing the proverbial camel through the eye of a needle. It is clear that any commitment to effective reform has been shelved by this Government. By delegating responsibility to individual State bodies for the day to day administration matters-receipt of documents and so on-a complicated bureaucratic procedure has been duplicated in each State whereby the interests of the general public have been largely ignored. So much for the Government's commitment to streamlining and efficiency as espoused in the razor gang's review. A far more sensible approach would be to establish a single national scheme with effective powers and reform provisions.

The package of legislation we have before us has been modified heavily and indicates the success of the powerful lobbying campaigns against the reform provisions. We can see how effective the reform provisions now are by the attitude of the Confederation of Australian Industry, which, as has been reported in the Australian Financial Review today, urged speedy enactment of this modified legislation after having strongly opposed earlier drafts last year. There will clearly be a great deal of work ahead of the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee which was established to assist the Ministerial Council. If this legislation is to provide national regulation of companies and securities, then it is vital that an ongoing commitment to reform be made publicly and that the work of the Review Committee be encouraged. There are many areas for potential reform that have been deferred by the Ministers at this stage-for example, the question of dealers who are members of a stock exchange being prohibited from being directors of public companies, public companies being required to lodge quarterly reports on profit and loss and turnover, an accounting standards review board, and provision of a statutory remedy for shareholders. The list goes on and on. These are all areas of great concern if we are serious about protecting the public from unscrupulous wheelers and dealers.

The Opposition has suggested a detailed list of amendments which would greatly improve this package of legislation, and I turn briefly to some of them. Amendment 5 (b) calls for the provision of statutory powers to the courts to enable the lifting of the corporate veil in circumstances such as that where a holding and subsidiary company acts as a unit, and where a private company acts as trustee for a trading trust. An earlier draft of the Bill in April 1980 contained clauses 167A to 167G which ensured that the public knew the entity with which they were dealing. These clauses set out the extent to which nominee company accounts had to disclose assets and liabilities of the trust, and provided penalty provisions for non-compliance. As honourable members are all aware, the setting up of $2 nominee companies which act as trustees for trading trusts means that the persons shown on the register as shareholders or directors are merely nominees or puppets of the persons who operate the trading trust. This means that the real assets in the operation belong to the trading trust and cannot be reached by creditors of the company. Creditors are therefore misled as to the actual ownership of assets standing in the name of the company. Moreover, the concept of directors' duties and responsibilities is eroded by this arrangement. Also, there is doubt as to whether defaulting officers' provisions can apply to officers of a nominee company when its business fails. Again, it is the unsuspecting public which pays the penalty because of inadequate legislative protection.

Clauses 167D to 167G of the April draft have now been dropped from this legislation. This leaves room for considerable speculation as to whose interests are being protected by the present companies law package. Clause 261 of the Bill tackles to a small degree part of the problem outlined in the trading trust situation to which I have referred. It gives a company power to require information from persons holding voting shares in the company in relation to the beneficial ownership of those shares. The company must enter in its register whether someone other than the holder of the share has a relevant interest, but only after it has obtained this information. However, the clause is limited in its application because it is dependent on the company's seeking information. There is no way in which a member of the public wishing to deal with the company can find out who is the beneficial owner of shares unless the company has already sought this information from its shareholders and published it in the register. Of course, there is no obligation for the company to seek this information, and it is unlikely that many will avail themselves of the opportunity. Thus, this clause is an inadequate substitute for substantial provisions which would regulate the activities of trading trusts.

Many other modifications and much watering down of the provisions have taken place as a result of pressure and lobbying from many groups with a vested interest in preventing greater regulation and control of their activities. The small investor is no match for the corporate giants in this legal jungle. We cannot rely on the companies and securities industry to regulate itself. This Parliament has a duty and an obligation to the people of Australia to ensure that effective public accountability provisions are implemented. The provision of a shareholders tribunal to provide a legal remedy in the protection of the interests of minority shareholders would be very much welcomed by small investors, but we do not find any provision for that. When we look at the modifications to the director's duty of care that are contained in this Bill we see that this Government appears to have little interest in the small investor. These provisions have been steadily eroded. The earlier draft imposed stiff maximum penalties. Now these have been replaced by a sliding scale providing for the higher penalties to apply only where dishonesty or fraud is proven. This implies that the Government regards the duty of care owed by directors of companies in their management of other people's money as not being of great importance. Most Australians, I believe, would disagree with that.

In the coming decade many people expect increased economic activity as a result of the resources boom. Now is the time to establish the machinery to create an effective national system for the regulation of the companies and securities industry. The Companies Bill before the House tonight represents too little, too late, and will be a big disappointment for all those Australians who expect a reliable national scheme. This was a great opportunity to enact substantial companies' reform measures, which were obviously needed in the past and which will be even more necessary in the 1980s. It is a pity that this Government has put the interests of narrow sectional groups ahead of the interests of all Australians.

—The honourable member for Hawker would know of the difficulty of getting States to agree to any one thing. SPEECH.PARA: I will refer to some issues that came to light during the debate. I do not wish to canvass the question of trading trusts which seems to have been adequately handled. I do not wish to get on to the question of reforms and so forth. I will refer to three simple matters. There is no doubt that the accounts of public companies in Australia vary in standard. I sent for and received in the mail today the report of Conzinc Riotinto of Australia Ltd. That company provides an enormous range of information in its report. This contrasts with a number of other public companies whose annual reports are scanty and certainly do not refer to any of the basic facts which are generally required. It is regrettable that many people who receive these reports do not even read them. Only last Friday I attended an accounting convention at which a very prominent company director said that he felt that many of the glossy reports put out by public companies were nothing less than an ego trip containing photographs about what the companies were doing. He said that the real relevance of the reports was lost. I can only endorse those remarks. I recommend to honourable members that, rather than look at the glossy pictures which is the easy part and therefore the least informative, they look at the notes on the accounts- the small print. This is highly recommended also in regard to prospectuses. The report to which I have referred contains some real information on the company's credit and general standing and shows its contract positions. It also alludes to the remunerations of directors and, more importantly-this brings me to another point which the honourable member for Parramatta raised-the question of small shareholders.

This company, which is one of our largest and most significant, has 40,655 shareholders. Some 38,466, or just on 95 per cent, have a shareholding of less than 5,000 shares. As a consequence, we need to look at the shareholdings of directors. This is contained in the small print. I have to take issue with respect to this aspect. One thing which becomes very apparent to me when looking at corporate accounts in Australia is the very small shareholding of most directors and particularly executive directors. The report shows that Sir Russel Madigan has 1,030 shares, L. J. Carden has 2,396, Sir Frank Espei, a former executive, has 533 and J. T. Ralph has 587 shares. Those people were all executive directors. On the other hand, one of the non-executive directors had 102,000 shares and another 1,067. Relatively small numbers of shares are held by executive directors these days. That is fairly common.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there anything about the number of nominees?
—They are certified as beneficial shareholdings. I, therefore, assume that that must be their holding.
—Ha, ha!

—I cannot do more than accept the man's word and I recommend that course to most other people unless proved otherwise. I say to those honourable members who are trying to interject that decrying people's honesty when one does not know much about it does not improve it. I take that stand in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Parramatta raised the question of employee reports. I commend that practice to companies. Far too infrequently is the dialogue between management and employee adequate. In the corporations that I have had association with, the relationship between management and employees has had a very big effect on the performance of those organisations. Certainly, the general efficiency and, certainly, profitability of those bodies have been contributed to by the high level of co-operation and co-ordination between management and employees. I have seen one or two companies put out what I would have thought were pretty reasonable reports to employees. By doing that they contributed to their employees' welfare and certainly their own. I hope more companies adopt that practice.

The honourable member for Hawker made an impassioned speech mainly on strong laws and the need to set those off against, presumably, weak laws. My commercial experience attests that, no matter how hard the laws are, we cannot protect a person from himself. It is a question, therefore, of seeing how relatively effective the laws are and to look at the consequences of those laws. The regulation of an industry is done mainly in ignorance. People do not understand an industry and therefore it is regulated. That is the first thing that is done. Bureaucrats have said to me on numerous occasions that the first thing one does when one does not understand an industry is to regulate it.

I am a strong believer in the concept of self-regulation. I have been proved to be wrong in certain areas where it has not worked out. I happen to think that that is regrettable because I do not believe that people coming from outside know what goes on within certain technical areas. I apply my remarks particularly to the capital market. I have seen people, whose names are well known publicly, appointed from outside to committees of stock exchanges and, to be realistic, they have not made a major contribution towards the running of those shows. So much for the competence of people from these outside bodies! It would have been better, in my view, if something had been done to upgrade those bodies and enforce what was sought on the participants in the stock exchange or the capital market than to appoint a well known outsider and say: 'We will fix it this way'. It does not work out that way.

The honourable member for Hawker made a most valid point when he asked: 'What is profit?' I recommend the consideration of this question to the Ministerial Council. The question of what is profit has implications far beyond, I think, what the honourable member envisages. It also raises in that context the whole question of current cost accounting and exactly what a company has within its books. This influences where one takes a profit in historical terms, current terms, cash-flow terms, depreciated terms or other terms. This has an enormous impact on the balance of a company. This leads me to another point raised by the honourable member in relation to proprietary companies and the fact that, therefore, they are a credit risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the few minutes available to me I wish to refer to the great problem of the extraordinary delays in hearing veterans' appeals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I refer particularly to cases of veterans without standing service during the Second World War. The relevant legislation, as it now stands, was introduced in 1979. It has resulted in a great deal more work for the Department of Veterans' Affairs and also for the Repatriation Commission. The work has to be carried out by the same number of employees with the result that the appeals are slipping further and further behind.

SPEECH.PARA: As an example I should like to refer to the case of Mr Leonard Allworth of Blacktown who was receiving the totally and permanently incapacitated pension. The Repatriation Board cancelled that pension from 17 April 1980 and increased the veteran's 100 per cent pension to the intermediate rate from 17 April 1980. That decision was made on 10 March 1980. He appealed to the President of the Repatriation Review Tribunal on 19 April 1980. The hearing was on 12 March 1981. The Tribunal was satisfied that the additional evidence presented by the Australian Legal Aid Office were relevant to the case and the matter was referred to the Repatriation Commission in accordance with section 107VI (2) of the Repatriation Act. This is as far as the case has gone to date. It is still awaiting a decision.

I wish to refer to another individual who had his case rejected by the Repatriation Commission on 27 November 1979. He lodged an appeal to the Repatriation Review Tribunal on 10 January 1980 in respect of his two disabilities. He was advised on 15 January 1980 that the matter had been referred to the Repatriation Review Tribunal. The case was to be heard on 9 June 1980 but on 19 May 1980 the Repatriation Review Tribunal decided that it would not consider any appeals on vascular disease until such time as the Esprud case had been considered by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

These two cases are examples of massive delays in the hearing of veterans' cases. Some of these cases go back years. It is simply due to the attitude of the Government which altered the legislation in 1979. It has made the whole procedure much more complicated but has not increased the staff numbers to cope with it. This is causing a great deal of undue concern and grief to a large number of veterans. Some of them will not even be alive by the time their cases are finally heard. I think it is well and truly time that the Government did something on this issue.
